description: Crab so good you'll get one to go after eating one inside!  The crab and shrimp cocktail was over stuffed with the freshest seafood. Our service was great. The bay shrimp salad with home made thousand island dressing was delicious. The lobster bisque was tasty. But the star was definitely the whole crab! Its no wonder there are no Red Lobsters in the city limits of SF. lol
author: Dan A.

description: Too me this place was gross. My fiance really wanted seafood so we made our way through the traffic and crowds to get here. I'm not a huge seafood fan but was willing to try the crab. I ordered a Cesar Salad with bay shrip. YUCK! The menu stated the best Cesar Salad, yeah it wasn't. I, not being a huge seafood fan, as stated above didn't know what bay shrimp was so my bad for that but even so there was nothing good about the salad. The one star is for the crab my fiance ordered, which wasn't bad. He enjoyed it. The service was okay. The bathroom was discusting! The toilet wouldn't flush correctly and there was toilet water all over the floor. I could hardley breath and there was no toilet paper. We were also charged an additional fee for something and not told in advance about it.
author: Holly I.

description: Watery clam chowder!! WTH!!! Seriously need a new recipe.
author: Letie W.

description:
I've never  liked clam chowder. My boyfriend is obsessed, though, so while in the area we had to find "the best."

It can be intimidating trying to search for chowder on this strip, as every place has it, and the prices are comparable. The first factor that sets Nick's apart is the cleanliness. Nick's was the cleanest, by far. All of the food was covered and the surfaces were all sanitary. He also wasn't obnoxious or pushy, he just offered us samples of his lobster bisque, clam chowder and crab chowder. All three were sensational. I even got a bowl of clam chowder to go. It was creamy and true to the New England standard without being overly "fishy". The only clam chowder I'll ever eat.
author: Janet R.

description: Nick's Lighthouse is our normal stop for clam chowder and fresh steamed crab whenever we are in San Francisco.  We were visiting Fisherman's Wharf a few weekends ago since we were nearby for a wedding and it didn't disappoint as always.  They have the best clam chowder around and the crabs are succulent, especially with a side of the butter sauce.  Customer service is always excellent even when it gets super busy.  Only down side is their bathroom is located in the back and it is right next to some dining tables.  Other than this I'd definitely recommend eating here.
author: Sunshine S.

description:
My bf LOVES crabs and when my friend told me it was crab season, we headed over to the wharf. He chose Nick's Lighthouse after we walked down the sidewalk filled with options and ordered a crab. I got clam chowder and fried calamari. We stood in the back and enjoyed our meal. 

We came back here with my parents and sat in the restaurant part. Our server was super friendly and joked with us throughout dinner. The food was AMAZING compared to the sidewalk cafe. We had both the clam chowder and lobster bisque bread bowls. The soup was hot and the bread bowl was soft. My linguine con vongale was really good. My dad enjoyed his grilled halibut, but my bf's mahi mahi wasn't that great. He said it tasted a big dry and weird. Then we went outside and bought some crabs for a late nite snack.

Overall, we had a great time. The sidewalk cafe is great for a quick fix and crabs. The dining room is great for the bread bowls and a fun experience. They said crab season is going to last for another 5 months! Woohoo, we're coming back!
author: Gladys C.

description:
Awkard.  Painful.  Tasteless.

Nick's - where the clam chowder is a misnomer for bland potato soup and the cioppino is as salty as a msg-laden mu shoo pork from Chinatown.

Nick's - where the servers are dense, and offer off-color, sarcastic remarks.  (They smile)

Nick's - where, when, how, WHY didn't I take a second to go with my gut and double check with yelp?  Should have fished for my own food in the Bay.

Nick's - embarrassed that I even gave this place a try.

$ whatever it is, not worth it :(  
(good bread)
author: Jane L.

description: I've been here twice. Went back the second time because i loved it so much the first time. The price is very good for its location (everything in fisherman's warf is expensive) $100 fed 4 people, including drinks, appetizer and main course. Cant remember what i had the first time but i had fettuccine Alfredo with shrimp the second time. They gave me the option between the big shrimp or the small bay shrimp, i chose the small and they were really tiny but there was a generous amount in my plate, enough for leftovers for the net day. I would def go back when the occasion arises.
author: Lena E.

description:
Say what crab chowder?!?
Omg I found this to be my fave!! It is absolutely delicious on a cold night it was soo good and tasty ohhh and the bread my my my yummo!! Awesome service and great food!!
author: arlene d.

description:
C'mon, all the restaurants along this row are slightly overpriced, cramped tourist traps, right? For what it is, this place is fine. I got a pint of beer for $5 with my bread bowl of clam chowder, and I was a happy camper. I've got to take off 1 star for cleanliness (our table wasn't clean...eww), and another because their combination cocktail (shrimp and crab meat) was a total rip-off--we're talking those teeeeeny shrimp that come frozen in a big bag, and odd-tasting crab meat, and not much of either.

I'll stick to the chowder and beer, but this isn't a bad place to come into to get out of the cold.
author: Ramon E.

description: The experience was so worth it. As they cut the lobster in half and cleaned it, dipped it in a tub of boiling water for a few seconds was very mouth watering. The Lobsters where fat and juicy, not robbery at all. I asked for clarified butter and soaked it in lemon juice. It was an awsome experience.
author: Jude J.

description:
I didn't like the crab sandwich. The bread was hard as a brick and so hard to eat since it was as thick as a brick.. The crab was meh. Price was high. Overall I hated the fact that I was surrounded by a near shat experience every time I tried to find seating across the street.. Fark you seagulls, go away and go fishing. 

I also tried my roommates popcorn shrimp. It kind of sucked. Guess It looked better than it tasted.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Crab and chowder on the wharf are legendary. Unfortunately, it's very hit and miss. Nick's Lighthouse is no different. It's a divey little crab shack with weird decor and pretty scrumptious chowder. If you feel like grabbing some crab from the stand in front of Nick's instead of sitting down inside the prices and flavor will be the same. But if you you're draggin' along the pier with a cutie, and you feel like gazing at her beautiful eyes over a lukewarm goblet of crab cocktail, mosey on inside. 

Here's what I do: 
-Order the garlic bread.
-Hope they remember to bring it. 
-Avoid the crab cocktail. 
-Don't miss the crab chowder (clam is out).
author: Chanti B.

description:
The only two reason I ever go out to the wharf is to have Red Bull on tap at one of the bars, the other reason is because occasionally some of my acquaintances from throughout the Bay want to visit SF and want to go here like tourists!

And so my high school friend dragged me here for a bread bowl. Which I totally misheard as "Red Bull" which is the reason I agreed to get my skinny beautiful butt out to the wharf. I mean, really, say "Bread Bowl" out loud, sort of muffle it, and it sounds just as if you were saying "Red Bull." And since I love Red Bull, more than anyone else on earth, of course I was tempted!

The first thing was, finding a parking spot that would be validated. I have no clue why she wanted to go here but whatever. The place totally stinks. See, I understand fish smells rotten after 12 hours of continuous services, but they don't clean it up, that's the problem. So that alone, was a bad thing.

I dislike Europeans so much because they are so slow. In a tiny restaurant where everyone is waiting for a table an European couple took their sweet time taking out quarters, 5 dollar bills, and 1 dolla bills trying to figure out a tip when they had put it on charge. They double checked, they took their glasses and made sure not a single drop or soda, was left in the glass. I was getting so mad.

The Red Bull Bread Bowl was nothing good. My friend didn't like it. My calamari was whatever. My other friend's burger was also whatever.
So whatever. Don't come here. 
Whatever.
author: Alexia R.

description: I hate the fact that they wrote tips in pen on my receipt. They automatically add 15% of your total.
author: Jasmine D.

description: First off we didn't even realize this place even existed. We were headed to Chowder Hut across the street when a man with broken English waved us toward him in front of what looked like a fish market bazaar. He pointed at the menu items and it seemed good, we asked him if they carried any beer, to which he replied "we have a full bar." So we were sold! The beer that they carried for "a full bar "only included Budweiser, modelo and corona. That isn't what we consider a fully stalked bar but we were already sat so I ordered anyway. I got a Bloody Mary and the linguini with mussels in a white wine sauce. The linguini had no flavor whatsoever! I added salt, pepper, butter, lemon and hot sauce before it was edible ! The mussels tasted like they were frozen then recooked. They had a strong fishy taste and odor to them. Not fresh at all considering that we were at Fishermans Warf. My boyfriend ordered a Long Island ice tea, he asked if we could add a shot of Jaegermeister to it which the server said that shouldn't be a problem.We got the bill to find out they charged us $10 to add one shot to our drink. Not once did the waitress let us know that they would charge extra for that, let alone $10. We also noticed while we were drinking it that it didn't we really couldn't taste the jaeger. So we asked to speak to the manger. He came over holding a dirty shot glass telling us that they had put one shot in our drink and that it cost $10. I told him that was ridiculous, and  that a bottle cost that much and that we are not going to pay that much for a drink alteration. He began to make a scene in his own restaurant  and yelled us. He eventually gave in before he stormed off. Not to mention the waitress never checked up on us, filled up our waters, asked if we wanted desert or smiled at us once. This place was miserable and so are the workers. DO NOT COME HERE!!!!
author: Julia D.

description:
If I can review and say a place deserves "0" stars, I would for this place.

Decor - I didn't expect much to begin with given this is not supposed to be an extremely nice place anyways given that it's in a touristy area but the inside was worse than expected.  Cramped.  How do overweight people even fit in the seats?  I had trouble myself.  FAIL overall!  If they were trying to accomplish something, I didn't get it.

Service - horrible.  Rude, slow.  

Food - elementary in both presentation and taste.  Cooked by someone who just began lessons in the kitchen. I didn't expect much, again, but this was worse than that.

Better off staying outside at the stands - but just not the stands operated by this same restaurant.  I've had better next door.  Bleh.  What a waste of money.  I'm so angry at myself.
author: JBean C.

description: This place is great. First off- you eat outside, standing up. Period.  (it is small and tiny inside, so don't bother going in unless to use the toilet.) The crab chowder bread bowl is where it's at!  Anyone who says it's bland must not have taste buds. The guys and gals who work outside are pretty entertaining as they holler at the passer-bys. During the day there's music across the way, so the whole area has a good vibe. Watch out for ruthless birds.
author: Jina E.

description: 1 star for the service. Choice of Lobster bisque, clam chowder or seafood salad. It is complimentary with the meal. The bisque would not sell on its own. I left out the lobster as Nick's did too. I ordered the 1/2 crab. Poor thing must have become emaciated in its attempt to escape the traps as there was not much to it in the legs or body. My wife got the shrimp skewers. Not restaurant quality, more like fast food. The sides asparagus, was more the pieces you would cut off in preparation (tough and stringy), only two tips. Saffron rice had little flavor. If you choose to eat here, at least try something else
author: GREG J.

description:
Service was terrible.   Went to Nick's today with a group of friends.  Two of us stopped at Nicks to try the crab cakes, garlic fries for my daughter and crab cocktail.  The young lady that took my order, took my money then didn't bother to fill my order.  After 10 minutes, with no one else standing in front of the glass case, I asked if my food was coming, she replied yes it was coming.  After another few minutes she counted out her register and left!   I patiently waited while more orders were filled and then approached another employee to inquire about my order and he said he knew nothing about it but He promptly filled my order.  

After the 15+ minute wait, I received old garlic fries (my daughter didn't even finish them) and watery crab.  My other friend that ordered the crab cakes promptly got a stomach ache after eating them.

There are a plenty of sidewalk vendors along the street where you can get the same food with better service.  Avoid this place.
author: Richard T.

description:
During a recent trip up North, this was one of the busiest vendors for clam chowder bread bowl. So instead of Boudin's, we wanted to just grab and go and be on the pier.

The scenery isn't much, but the food was great. Just what was needed after a long drive.

We also with some fish and chips (normally curly fries, but got garlic fries instead). It  was delicious. Whole garlic cloves chopped and seasoned with green onions and fries. You can not go wrong with fries.
author: Janet K.

description:
Food was great! I went with a group of friends, we ordered dungeness crab, oysters and the lobster bisque. The oysters were a little overpriced than they were priced outside of the shop. The shop advertised $1.50 per oyster, but inside of the restaurant they charged $23 and change for a dozen. 
The seats were a little tight and it was a little small, so if you're not petite, then maybe it will be better to eat outside. 

Overall, a great place to eat, I would definitely eat there again! :)
author: Adriana S.

description: 5Stars on the food.... Spicy Crab was Amazing BUT..... the booths & bathrooms should be Illegal... with the money they make in that place i'm sure there is enough in the budget for some upgrades.
author: John J. D.

description:
I was looking forward to getting some fried food as I was sampling around the pier for food. 

I got some calamari and chips.  Unfortunately, it left my mouth a bit distasteful and me feeling very groggy.  The food seemed like it had been sitting in the window all day.  The breading on the calamari wasn't very even, if there was any at all.  However, the squid itself was in large strips and tasted wonderful.  The chips were curly seasoned fries. But again, cold and filled with the taste of grease and oil.  I honestly couldn't finish the rest of the food so after I ate all the calamari, I clandestinely put my food down on a lamppost and walked away so someone or something else could enjoy my leftovers.
author: Calvin T.

description:
Nick's Lighthouse is located in the middle of about another 10 seafood places.  It's hard to figure out which one to go to when they all look the same.  My P.I.C. has been to Nick's before so we figured we would go there.
The smell is your typical sea food fishy smell... not so pleasant; however lets face it... the smell lets you know that it's fresh.
The inside of the restaurant it is big- there is plenty of room for large parties. 
The menu has the typical clam chowder bowls, fish and chips, oysters and all kinds of other sea food dishes.  Since I knew what I wanted I didn't do much browsing.  I opted for the clam chowder bowl and my P.I.C. ordered fish and chips.  The service was good- nothing out of the norm.  Quick and efficient.
Our food was served a 15-20 minutes later.    Can't complain-tasty, portion size was ok, and prices are about average!

I would recommend this place if you are not sure where to go- good service and fresh food!
author: diana r.

description:
With all the places in the Wharf yelling to come to their joint, I was told that I should come here. Everyone was super friendly and at the mention of crab chowder, we were given samples of all three soups (crab chowder, clam chowder and lobster bisque). We settled on a bread bowl of crab chowder, a whole crab (weighed to be a fair $15) and calamari & chips. My friend who ordered the calamari unfortunately got mauled by a seagull and Nick's was kind enough to give her some more before the flock got closer to her. The crab was incredible, perfectly cooked and cracked in all the right places. I didn't ask, but I would have loved butter with it. 

If i'm back here, i'd come here again! But i'm sure curiosity will get to me and I'll venture to another spot as well.
author: Marissa F.

description:
I guess when you come to a busy tourist area, you can't expect good service, let alone great.  That place was the only place that had a table ready.. we ordered 3 clam chowders w/ the sourdough bread bowls and an order of onion rings.. the order took quite some time to arrive and our server was not sincere or quick w/ our request nor did she really check in on us but I guess it was my fault for having high hopes for a busy ass place.  

The clam chowder was good.. the onion rings were exceptional.. 

Parking of course was terrible but hey, that's SF.  We were lucky to have parking in the free area not far from the Wharf area at all!
author: Tram N.

description:
Let me first off start by saying that Fisherman's Wharf in SF is awesome.

Unfortunately Nicks, isnt all that great. The tabels were awfully cramped together, i get that its a small place but the booths were pretty uncomfortable. 2. the server was really rude, and didnt seem to care at all that we sat down. 3. the chowder we ordered was pretty cold. so they took it back and gave me a new one or they heateed it up some more and it was good after but first impressions are everything. The crab chowder was aite, nothing to brag about, and the calamari was good, not great. Portions were pretty small for the price, and the garlic bread was the highlight of the meal.

The worst part of it all was when we tried to get our bill i watched for a good 10 minutes my server chatting it up standing next to the cash register just laughing and carrying on not even touching the machine to process our check. Customer Service is #1 no matter where you go.

Needless to say, Nick's #5....Once is more then enough.
author: Rob G.

description: To the hell with all these other bad reviews! I come to SF 2 times a week for work from Los Angeles and know the best places to go and not to go to. If your visiting the wharf this is the best place on the small strip. Their seafood is always fresh and the service is a 10.
author: Ed G.

description:
TL;DR: Good chowder but they lied costing me $13

I came here with a couple friends to try some clam chowder and heard this place was pretty good. We drove, so we parked at the Pier 39 parking which had 1 hour free parking with validation. Eating clam chowder would not take one hour so it was perfect. We came to the stand and first asked if they did validation for Pier 39 parking. They first said they weren't too sure but then they confirmed that they did. Great but then they added that they had a $10 minimum purchase policy for clam chowder. No big deal since there was 5 of us and we were going to share. So we ordered a clam chowder with bread bowl and a popcorn shrimp. The total was $13.

Actual food review: The chowder was good and the shrimp was generic. The chowder had a good flavor and was decently chunky. Warning: The popcorn shrimp is deceivingly big because it has a bed of curly fries underneath all the shrimp. Not worth the $6.50 (approx.) that they charge. 

We finished up and went back to the parking lot. Thinking we were all validated we went to exit the lot but the machines said they could not read the validation card. We had to call over the attendant and ask to figure out what was wrong. After the attendant came back with the card, he told us that the card got corrupted/ruined and that there was no validation. We had to pay $7 for the parking.

As a result I am furious. I may be a little harsh but the people working at Nick's essentially scammed us into buying an extra item by lying to us that they validated for Pier 39. Because they lied we lost another 7 dollars on top of the 6.50 that we paid for the popcorn shrimp that we would have never bought.

Sure this may have been an isolated case but if Nick's employees are willing to lie for a quick buck even once, I would avoid this place. There are plenty of other places to get some good/better clam chowder.
author: Samuel J.

description: This place was horrible.  I'll still give 2 star though because the service was good, but the portions suck here.  Not only that the pricing is a little bit more than ridiculous.  Things here aren't what they seem.  The food isn't doesn't even taste that great.
author: Daniel R.

description: I am giving this only two stars because the waiter here was very rude to us for his anger on some other table. I heard him say I hate table 4 which I do not think we should had heard. The food lobster bisque was great and the oyster po boy was so so I give them two stars for the food
author: Pradnesh K.

description: the nice waiter talked us into the seafood platter for two at $110 bucks and said it would be a meal we would never forget ,well he was right .A 1 ld lobster that was over cooked , a small crab , three mealy yucky clams , I hope we don't get sick ! 4 tiny shrimp ,3 oysters and some calamari salad .after dinner we were starving , the waiter told the manager who gave us a comp dessert . Cheese cake and teramasu , I literally bounce the cheese cake on my plate and it stood on end , just horrible, please eat anywhere else in San Fran this place is terrible .and the kind waiter told the manager about the rubber cheese cake and I saw him  shrug his shoulders and say too bad ! What terrible service ,I would never ever return
author: Tom C.

description:
3.5 stars.  This place is A-OK to eat and out of all of the many tourist restaurant traps on Fisherman's Wharf, this one is the best of them.

I love my husbone despite the fact that he loves tourist traps.  We were in Fisherman's wharf, looking for some seafood and we kept seeing these people walk by with large bread-bowls with steaming chowder.  It looked mighty good.. we walked in..

A little seafood shanty with full-on checkered table cloths and snarky wait staff to boot.

San Franciscan sourdough bread to start.  We each ordered a cup of the clam chowder.  Creamy with chunks of dungeoness crab meats.  It hit the spot.  I ordered the mussels in a tomato broth ($17)- plump, juicy mussels - you can't go wrong with that.  I made sure to hoard the rest of the sourdough bread from my companions so I could sop it up with the tomato broth.

My husbone ordered a linguini dish with chunks of dungeoness crab meat and 5 large tiger prawns ($18).  This dish was very good.  My sister ordered a half dungeoness crab ($21).. it was kind of small for the market price they were charging, but she loves crab.

All in all, this place is A-OK for a touristy-located restaurant.
author: Thu V.

description: Had the crab sandwich..it did not taste fresh.  The seagulls enjoyed it, I should of had the chowder in a bowl.
author: Rene K.

description:
Nooo bueno!

We stopped here because along the row of hooters and callers along Fishermans' Wharf row restaurants, this one sounded the best.

It was cramped inside once we got there, it was cramped with little space between the table and where you sit on your seat. For my wife, it was especially hard with her being 15 weeks pregnant. 

She got a shrimp cocktail for $10.75....which is OK. But for the bay shrimp (small ones) and a small amount that you get, it's TERRIBLE. I would expect you get maybe a cup of shrimp, maybe a little more than than considering how small they were,but she only got maybe a 1/4 to 1/2 cup, and a little dollop of cocktail sauce on the side.

She also got their "famous" clam chowder. Ugh..not very good. Runny, not very flavorful (had to add lots of salt & pepper), and itty bitty titty little clam pieces that didn't seem fresh. 

I got the Linguine with Butter Cream sauce and mussels, and that was pretty good for the price. $13.75 for that and a soup or salad. 

My meal was the reason I gave this place 2 Stars. 

The service was...forgettable. Not great, but not the worst I've ever received either. 

I would NOT come back here again, based on my experience and looking at reviews of Crab House #2.
author: Jaren L.

description: Great customer service.... When slow. My girl and I only stop in to get the spicy pasta on the specials menu. I forgot the name but its amazing, if you like spicy food of course. The clam chowder is ok. The fish and chip are above average but not the best I've had. Overall I was generous with 4 stars but I couldn't give it 3.
author: Hisham A.

description: 4.5 for the crab and the lobster bisque. Fresh, tasty, and I want to go back now. San Francisco is a great place. My guy and I had checked out other restaurants on the wharf but we decided that this restaurant looked the most enticing. We got lots of crab for the price and a choice of soup: lobster bisque or clam chowder. The crab and both soups are really good. We were stuffed for a good while.
author: Evelyn T.

description: Thought it was good but not great.  Bread was tough & didn't seen very fresh.  Sampled Lobster Bisque & Clam Chowder both were average.  Wife had fish & chips, the fish was kinda floppy.  I had smoked salmon pasta that I thought was too rich.  Wouldn't go back if I was buying.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I have to agree with Rob on this one. Definitely cramped. I can deal with cramped aisles, since it is a small place, but cramped booths. That just makes it' hard to enjoy your food. I give the clam chowder with the bread bowl 3 stars. Very tasty and warm but could have used a little more clams. There were two things that brought down my thoughts of this place. One the service was pretty mediocre. I was just shy of snapping my fingers just to try and get my waiters attention. Second was the fish, it tasted fine but I was expecting a something a little more kick and flavor especially for the price I paid. It tasted like I made it on my skillet at home. Actually that's an overstatement because I can't cook fish that well.

All in all I'd probably go back just for the chowder and bread bowl.
author: Roberto F.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf
Have to take the family or out of towners to the Wharf?
Fun seafood restaurant; crowded; keeps you out of the cold
Middle range between expensive and eating crab on the street
Good clam and crab chowders
Very nice seafood salads
Friendly food servers; great host
Bonus: 3 hours validated parking at the Wharf; can run up to Ghiradelli's for an ice cream
author: Rosquete B.

description: If you want a clam chowder or crab or whatever without any meat this is your place. A place full of potato and tomato sauce to trick tourists.
author: Karoline P.

description: Perfect example of a business working only as hard as it has to - and that is - not that hard - being located smack dab in the middle of fisherman's wharf they could beat their customers with sticks and still run a pretty successful operation. I got the crab cocktail which came in a container slightly larger than the plastic taqueria salsa dish, roughly a half the size of a Dixie cup, and i paid just under $7 for the privilege ... thanks nicks lighthouse - for showing all of us just how little value you need to provide in order to stay in business at a strategically awesome business location.
author: Oleg H.

description: After checking some of the poor reviews I was a little uncertain about eating here but I did any ways. Yes I was lured in by the guy out front. I ordered the fish n chips and half of crab all was very tasty and pleasing I had no problems with this place. Friendly food taste good and price is what was expected. I wrote this review a few days later and never got sick. So if your unsure where to eat and this guy drags you in and you open yelp checking the reviews grab a bite to eat you will enjoy.
author: Louis C.

description: I have been going here for decades. The lobster bisque in a bread bowl is my favorite in the world. Clam chowder in a bread bowl is delicious. Wierd, but the corn dogs are really delicious too. I live in LA and used to live in Sacramento and every trip that I make to the bay area, even if it's Oakland or other surrounding bay area cities, I always eat at least once at Nick's on the pier.
author: NoCal Jes A.

description:
This is my husband and I's favorite restaurant in the Bay Area for some yummy lobster!
Their fried calamari is great
They also have stands outside for their San Francisco's famous clam chowder bread bowl which can also be ordered inside at the restaurant as well.

I always recommend this restaurant to everyone I know.
author: Mimi z.

description:
This was place was awful!!! It ruined my family trip. We. were hungry so we decided to try Nicks,  what a mistake. 

It took 15 minutes to get a waitress to even take our order another 10 for the drinks to come out . By the time we got soup it was ice cold. To top it all off my daughter had something that had to be what looked like plastic or a piece of finger nail in it! 
Only to be told some bs that it's some part of the napkin   . This ruined our vacation especially since we all are now sick after eating this "food". Honestly this pace deserves a 0!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
We stopped by Nick's for a chowder bowl and a couple freshly steamed crabs. Compared to the restaurants nearby, the crabs were half the price (though still expensive) at over $10/lb. Two crabs and a bread bowl came out to about $40 but we were pretty stuffed by the end of it.

The chowder could have had more clam in it but it was otherwise satisfyingly true to my childhood memories. The drawn butter was a highlight of the night. squirt one of those lemons in there and the sweet crab meat tastes so much sweeter.

I must note that their seafood case was pretty sad looking. I'd stick with the live crab.
author: Bye Y.

description: This place is cute but super small because it's crammed in that little strip in Fisherman's Wharf. I couldn't decided between ordering the lobster bisque or the clam chowder. But then I chose the chowder and it was TASTELESS. The portions of the seafood platter we ordered was a little skimpy. There were only like 2 and half fried oysters. This place gets 3 stars, not that great but not that bad.
author: Briget P.

description: My out of town guests wanted to try this place so I had to agree.  WORST EVER! Awful Service, awful clam chowder and crab sandwich!  To top it off, they automatically add 15 Percent tip to your bill!  BEWARE of this establishment!
author: Marie S.

description:
They tricked my friend into buying the crab.  She wanted some fish and chips, but the waiter pushed a hard sale on her and she went for it.  I had the fried oyster poboy.  It was all okay, but $30 for a crab seemed a bit too expensive for me.

Note: don't go by the map on Yelp*  It guided us out to a bunch of warehouses when in fact, Nick's Lighthouse is packed between a bunch of restaurants right off the main drag.
author: Lucius M.

description: Very disappointing service quality. They become super nice if you order lobsters or bottles of wine. We tried sourdough bread that was not sour at all but it was just hard to bite. Clam chowder and fried squid are below average...will never visit here again.
author: Henry P.

description:
Went here for Easter dinner :) It was cold and rainy as heck outside. We got here to find no waiting, score!! The seating was a bit tight. I'm not a big person and I felt pretty cramped, so don't eat too much or it might take the jaws of life to pull you out of the booth. lol. just sayin' 
The Clam chowder was yummy, as was the crab cocktail and steamed clams. My Friend order the crab and lobster canneloni, it was really, really, really good!
author: Melissa M.

description:
So me and my gf flew into Oakland, took the bart to SF, checked into our room and were craving some clam chowder and crab.  Of course we headed down to Fishermans Wharf and after walking past all the outside vendors and peeking into the restaurants we decided on Nicks.  So glad we did.  The guy at the door told us about the crab special and guaranteed he would hook us up.  

We started off with some warm, crusty bread which was delish.  We both had clam chowder.  It was really, really thick but very tasty.  And once you dip the bread into the chowder mmm mmm mmm.  We had to order extra bread.  Then the plate of crab arrived.  Although we opted to buy one whole crab the guy really did take care of us because we had just about two full crabs on our plate and it was sweet and moist.  Add some lemon and butter and we had a great meal.  

Overall we enjoyed the whole experience.  The food, the service, the cold beers.  Definately worth it to sit and enjoy a nice lunch here.
author: Joanna V.

description:
Over the years I came to have a liking for the little "strip of stand up restaurants" by the other side of pier 39. These tiny stands offer cheaper but still yummy foods for a fraction of the cost of eating at a "sit-in" restaurant. Compared to "standard" restaurants by the pier which may cost upwards of $18+ a person, you can usually get items that cost $6-7 individually by dining at these stands. Big difference. 

Nick's lighthouse was (used to be) one of the better ones. But today's impression has left me saying goodbye to the "lighthouse" forever. I had the chowder, which tasted slightly better than boiled water that looks like chowder but isn't. The lady I spoke with was nice enough to offer me a taste of the lobster bisque but was not nice enough when I signed the slip to pay:

Lady: Hey you... don't you know how to sign? 
Me: (In my head) ok....I only signed about 100000x10000 slips before...

I grumbled knowing that $7.50 was forever gone from my wallet only to perpetuate more tasteless chowder for other suckers... Only you can stop the cycle of oppression now!
author: Chris S.

description: Was in town for an opening of an art gallery and decided to have dinner here.. WHAT HAPPENED?!?!? This place has totally gone down hill and done what most of these tourist traps do... SPOIL..... Granted the seating accommodations are minimal and are tight at best, you cant excuse the stupidity of weighers and your cooks, my order was messed up not once but twice... drinks never came .... which they still tried charging for... the food was less than subpar at all, fires were burned and soggy, fish coated with layers and layers of grease, and shrimp salad about 6 of the super small mini shrimp.... Of course the owner manager guy standing outside in a rain type jacket asked how our meal was remembering us, we simply said BAD..... he kept trying to say the usual desperate business going under statement.... come on back we will be better next time... well sorry buddy there wont be a next time for as much as you charge....
author: Nathan P.

description: Food was ok, hit or miss. Bad clam chowder and some of the slowest service I've experienced. Would not come back.
author: Sergio S.

description:
Something must have been "off" for me on this recent trip. I'm not liking places others love and I'm loving places that aren't getting good reviews.

I loved Nicks. I had fried fish and loved it. The breading was tasty and even though it came from the buffet-tray thing (we did walk-up, not sit-down) it tasted fresh and just out of the fry-daddy!  The fried prawns were good, but nothing remarkable. 

He had the crab and loved it.  Thought the price was good and we had a great lunch.
author: Joanna R.

description:
My roommate and I went to Fisherman's Grotto for dinner at 10:30pm last night.  Yes, that's late and as soon as we arrived, we knew it, seeing how all the stands were already closing up.  Nick's however was still open so we went into the restaurant to stay out of the cold.  

Although we came here originally for clam chowder, we ended up ordering half a dozen oysters on the half shell, a cup of crab chowder, a cup of lobster bisque, and their sourdough garlic bread.

The oysters came first and I was excited to see how big they were.  But the cocktail sauce, which tasted too much like ketchup, kind of ruined it for me.  Why would cocktail sauce taste like ketchup?!  Good thing I still had my Tabasco and lemon.  Otherwise, a fit would've ensued.  Lol.

Our bread came next.  2 slices, heavily coated with butter, garlic and basil.  It was good but honestly, $4 for 2 thin slices of bread?!  It's bread for crying out loud!  2 more slices wouldn't hurt!  Maybe I'm just too used to complimentary bread when I eat out.  Like in Dolce's, Ketchup, Morton's, Cheesecake, and even CPK.  Oh pooey.

Next came our small cups of crab chowder and lobster bisque.  The crab chowder kind of tasted like clam chowder.  Except it's crab.  Or at least that's what they claim is in there.  The lobster bisque on the other hand was really good with its strong flavorful lobster taste.  Don't expect to find any pieces of crab or lobster in the chowders although you will find cubes of potatoes.

It was about $31, not including tip, for the little seafood we were able to indulge in.  For the price, I will not be coming here again since I know there are better places adjacent to Nick's.  Actually, I don't think there are any factors that will get me to come back again except for the lobster bisque.  If I can't find better lobster bisque elsewhere that is.
author: Linh V.

description:
I received an apologetic email from what seems to be the proprietor of Nick's Lighthouse. Despite the service we received the night we went to the restaurant, I must say that an owner who check on Yelp to ensure customer satisfaction is commendable. True, it doesn't take away the bad experience, but it does show that the restaurant understand customer satisfaction. 

Props to you, Nick's Lighthouse. I will venture through your doors again and maybe this time, I'll leave behind my spongebob costume.
author: L _.

description: Amazing Clam Chowder Breadbowl but not so amazing when you have gnats flying around you while trying to enjoy your food. Ever since then my bf and I haven't been back. It's a shame because we loved coming their for our anniversaries.
author: Maria R.

description: Can you spell tourist trap. Avoid and save yourself some dough. Everything but the crab was terrible. No flavor. The sides were good for compost. Really should think about replacing the chef.
author: Scott K.

description:
It was a cozy red checkered tablecloth sea shanty restaurant kind of day. With the rain pouring and the wind gusting, we wanted to get our chowder on and warm up with a view of the yachts being tossed about on the wharf. 

There's a whole row of restaurants displaying their fresh fish outside still alive and kicking, but I'm glad we chose Nick's. Dungeness crab is at it's best right now, so we ordered a half and got cracking! It was a big meaty one, and when served up with butter, cocktail sauce and lemon, it was delish. All that was missing was a bib.

I ordered the New England clam chowder I was craving, and while it wasn't the best I've had, the bread bowl it was served in added that crusty, sourdough kick that brought it all together and warmed me to the core. Pair that up with an Anchor Steam and you'll leave happy as a clam. I gotta give Jorge the server a shout out -- he's amazing.

We finished off the day with a visit to the Penny Arcade, but where the hell was Bush Man? I'm a little sad I didn't see him. I'd been anticipating that scare all day!
author: Nicole G.

description: The items displayed on Nick's menu tastes pretty awesome, and the pricing structure is not too bad, either.: $10-$15 per whole crab steamed, $4.50 lobster bisque (pureed with tomato), $5.75 crab bisque.
author: Cathaleya C.

description: I've been coming to Nick's off and on for about 15 years now...I had just finished the CFA exam and I wanted to treat myself to a great chowder bowl. I've also eaten in the restaurant and the food is pretty good. Not too pricey for San Francisco and the quality of the food is good....the seafood is fresh every day.
author: Jim A.

description: Gordon Ramsey please help.  I had the fettuccine Alfredo with crab it was surprisingly delicious, but for me the restaurant did not have the right ambience it was dark,I think that were two different things playing on the radio. I think the space could bee better used.
author: Peanutbtr k.

description: Lobster Bisque was great!  Clam Chowder...not so much.  My boyfriend really liked the clam chowder though so maybe I'm just not a fan of that kind of soup.  The fish and chips were okay.  Nothing to write home about.  It was quick service and the server was friendly.
author: Kari C.

description:
Maybe my expectations were a bit high since SF Fisherman's Wharf is known for seafood and clam chowder, but being centrally located on the strip of the Grotto at Fisherman's Wharf, Nick's Lighthouse did not meet my expectations.

My roommate and I were on a mission to get some yummy seafood/clam chowder at Fisherman's Wharf.  Not knowing which restaurant/stand to go to, we picked out Nick's since it was right on the strip (we were also there a bit late and they were one of the few places still open).  We ordered basil and Parmesan garlic bread, a cup of crab chowder, a cup of lobster bisque, and half a dozen of oysters on the half shell.  

The oysters were not the best I've had but still really good--on the bigger side for sure and fresh.  It came with horseradish, a generous serving of lemon slices, and cocktail sauce, although that tasted more like ketchup than what it's supposed to be.

For $4.95, the garlic bread looked like something I could've made at home myself, and the portion was a bit small.  The soups were both really good and flavorful, but they were both more of a puree than chowder and I was expecting more chunks of crab/lobster than what we got.  Once, again, portions were small for the price it was.

Overall Nick's Lighthouse has good food, but for the price we paid and  as a restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf, I definitely expected more.
author: Ashley S.

description: If the takeout clam chowder is indicative of their normal offerings, I can only say its a tourist trap.  I got a pint of chowder to compare against Boudin and I regret walking across the street.  The color was a pale green and somewhat off putting.  The flavor was spiked with thyme and there was limited seafood flavor.  Consistency was a big issue too as I tasted tons of cornstarch and not the richness of a roux.  Certainly not on par with the competition.
author: Dude D.

description:
If anyone wants to experience the SF way of eating Dungeness crab, Nick's Lighthouse is definitely NOT the place you would go to.  

My husband was visiting the bay area and wanted some Dungeness crab.  Man - he LOVES Dungeness crab! Anyways, I brought him to this area where there are 4-5 different street vendors selling everything seafood - crabs, oyster, calamari, crab cakes, clam chowder.  As we were browsing through, someone from Nick's Lighthouse was screaming for us to dine at their restaurant.  We just wanted some Dungeness crab and calamari, that's it.  I asked the guy if we would get the same deal inside the restaurant as we would if we purchased the same food from their street vendor and he said yes.  So my husband decided to try it out.  At least we can sit somewhere and eat.

Okay, so here goes the experience....
It was a nice beautiful day in SF, beezy but sunny.  As soon as we stepped inside, it was dark.  The restaurant has their lights dimmed, in the middle of the afternoon.  C'mon.  I wanted to enjoy the sun.  We sat at a booth near the door.  Our booth was super cramped.  My husband and I were busy stepping on each other's feet and it sucks when you are wearing flip flops. Ouch!  When the waitress came by to take our order, I asked for the price of the Dungeness crab.  They sell a 1.5 lbs crab for $27.50.  Outside they sold it for $10.99 per pound.  But they had to iterate that the order comes with a salad.  As for the calamari, the menu stated that it cost $11 & change, while the vendor sold it for $7.99.  My husband felt bad to leave, so we decided to stay and try it out.

Couple of complaints:
1.  The salad that came with the crab was soggy.  The leaves look wilted.  Appearance was not appealing.
2.  We order a half crab (3/4 lbs).  The plate was huge, but the portion was small.  They covered the whole plate with wilted salad and a few pieces of crab.
3.  Calamari, horrible.  No flavor.  Appearance: not good.  It look like they just grabbed a bunch of squid, battered it, and tossed it in the fryer.  The calamari was still doughy all clumped together.
4.  Service, horrible.  The waitress came by only to take our drink order, food order, and to deliver our meal.  She didnt come by anything in between to ask if everything was ok.  I needed a refill on my drink and I had to track her down.

Compliment:
Only one.  ONLY the crab tasted good.  but how can you screw up its natural flavor????
Ohh wait, there's one more.  The complimentary sourdough bread was decent.

Overall, the experience at this restaurant sucked for me.  I would never go back there.

If anyone happens to visit Fisherman's Wharf and wants Dungeness crab, just stick with the street vendors.  The guys that call out to you only wants to lure you into their restaurant and spend twice as much for the same food as their vendor.

As for a recommendation of where to get the best Dungeness crab..... anywhere.  They cant screw up the natural flavor of such a succulent crab. 

Hope this review helps you....
author: Louisa L.

description:
Total hole in wall stuck in the middle of all the restaurants at Fisherman's Wharf (not Pier 39). Great food, cozy atmosphere and efficient service. 

I think for the most part you can't go wrong with most places. Some are more white table cloth and others maybe a bit more rough, but Nick's is a happy middle ground. Booths make the experience more unique because your party gets to squeeze together and be cozy. The prices are obviously more than if you order outside, but not outrageous by any means. Plus, you get to sit and enjoy.

Never really ventured and tried much on the menu other than a few appetizers and the chowder bread bowls. To be honest, the bread bowl makes a hearty lunch. Not to mention, it is pretty cheap and gets you warm when it is cold and wet out. 

Nick's has a full bar, so it is great to have a beer or drink while eating your chowder. Are there better chowders? Maybe, but overall, this place is a solid find. We make it a point to head straight to Nick's everytime we are in SF to grab some chowder. 

Wait staff is very quick and friendly and you can tell they like to turn the tables quickly. That said, if you set the pace and let them know you are not in a rush, they tone down and work to your speed, which is nice.
author: Jason C.

description: Cool seafood place right on the water. I'm not a big seafood eater and only had the clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. So while being from New England and having lots of different chowders I found this one pretty good. Good amount of clams and the chowder was a good consistency. The best part was the sourdough bread bowl. They don't have bread bowls like this in New England. So the combo of the amazing bread bowl and the good chowder made for a great experience in my book. Now if they could only get those bread bowls back in New England.
author: Chris C.

description: I don't eat at the restaurant. I don't. I've eaten inside once and I can tell you it wasn't the best I've ever had. But why am I giving this place 5 stars? Because the street food is the best! For some bizzaro reason, there's a worm hole between the restaurant and the street dinning. The curbside dining option is really the way to experience San Francisco if you're a first timer. I always order a crab cocktail or full crab. Then I also order the lobster bisque and garlic fries. I also recommend the fried calamari. Let me be straight, I sell this place to all the undecided Asian tourists. I'm always using my native Mandarin and selling it! Come eat here. It's always good! I only eat at this place! And who can resist a tall Asian man sharing his crab! I sell it but really the curbside food sells itself.
author: Jon H.

description: Dungeness crab at the Fisherman's Wharf was the highlight of the day. It was rather hard making the right choice from the line of restaurants along the wharf, after a while we just walked into Nick's and ordered. Now...........The Spicy garlic Dungeness crab dish at Nicks made my b*******ks tingle...............a good sign...........not too spicy but a truly satisfying Dungeness crab meal.......
author: Stricky T.

description:
This is the last restaurant/stall at the end of the crab stands. 

The SO claims the dirtier the water in the pot, the better the flavor. Nick's Lighthouse wins for dirtiest pot! The guy outside tries really hard to get customers in by holding up a live crab at passerby. 

Service could have been better. Felt like they just wanted to get us inside, then we had to wait 5 minutes to be noticed by the wait staff. 

The restaurant atmosphere is cozy and intimate, with booth seating all around. The fried calamari could use a bit less bread coating and more flavor, but I love the red cocktail sauce, not too spicy. A whole crab for $28 comes with a side of salad or clam chowder. I would get chowder elsewhere, but the crab was good being cooked in the 'flavorful' pot!
author: Caroline S.

description:
I think I'm only getting my New England clam chowder in San Francisco from now on (especially in Nick's Lighthouse) or in Boston (if I ever get the lucky chance to go there someday).  Call my high-maintenance, but whatever.

I'm that serious.  I went here with 2 of my friends, and the clam chowder was that delicious.  Fresh from the Bay.  I'm not gonna even bother with ordering clam chowder in Sacramento where I live (unless someone can find a restaurant here with chowder that's up to par)
author: Hannah P.

description: Was walking around the pier and came across Nick's Lighthouse. We ordered to go really quick since we were on the way to dinner, but my boyfriend really wanted some raw oysters right then and there. So we got 6 pieces of oysters for $1.50 each. They were really busy outside in the to go stand, but the guy working there was really nice. Gave us some mix of their fried appetizers like calamari, curly fries, and shrimp while we waited for our oysters to be shucked. The fried stuff was just alright and the oysters were just okay too. They were kind of small, but 4 stars for great service and being able to get a couple of pieces of oysters to eat right then and there to fulfill our craving.
author: Thao V.

description:
I tried their crab chowder.  Sounds exciting; tasted like bland potato soup with some crab thrown in.  I didn't finish it -- a waste of calories.

I also tried their popcorn shrimp; there was no "pop" in the batter of this popcorn shrimp -- in fact, I think frozen popcorn shrimp is better tasting than this.  I actually ate 2 and gave the rest to a homeless man nearby.
author: Randi M.

description: Mediocre. The service and the food are OK. The prices are pretty high.
author: Jenya B.

description: This was terrible!!! Never again. The clam chowder and salad were literally the same temperature. The pasta didn't taste too bad. After we got our food we watched the host grab a lobster from the tank, wipe his hands on his apron, seat a party, clear a table, and never stopped to wash his hands. I literally felt sick before leaving. I had to stop 4 times on the way home to throw up. Just incase you are wondering, I did not eat anywhere else! Spent $45 on the worst stomach ache ever!! Don't go here....
author: K A.

description:
I felt tricked into coming in here. The sheep herder / guy at the front door somehow talked me into trying their chowder and ushering us in the door. The restaurant was crowded and seemed like a good spot I hadn't yet tried and so they sat us down and we were immediately greeted with sourdough bread and ice water.

I order the special - a bowl of clam chowder and the fettuccine with bay (baby) shrimp and bay (baby) scallops. Being that I LOVE scallops, I expected a great meal.

The clam chowder was one of the worse I've ever had. 1 star. For SF clam chowder to fail is hard, i've eaten it at the spots next door and they were both delicious and hearty. This one wasn't thick, contained very little clams, had WAY too much celery and onions, and lacked any distinguishable flavors. Do not get the chowder here, pretty nasty.

The fettuccine was alright. 2.5 stars. The cream sauce was pretty good, but the seafood lacked flavor (and was tiny). I did like the roasted tomatoes in the pasta. For a special, the seafood should have been of higher quality and marinated or flavored in some way. My friend liked it, I've had much better in my opinion.

This is one of the poorer spots in Fisherman's Wharf. You can easily goto Boudin's / the Grotto / Bubba Gump for a much better meal. Skip this one.
author: Chuck N.

description: We were in San Francisco for a week, and he first day we went to Nicks. We had their oyster po boys. Awesome!!! We had to go back again before we took off for Seattle.. We had a really great waiter named Justin.... We were gone for a week, and came back before we flew back home... Guess what.... We just had to go back it Nicks for one more oyster po boy!!! We tried a couple while we were gone, but that Boudin sourdough bread just can't be beat... And we were soooo glad to get Justin again for our waiter... He remembered us!!! Will be the first place we hit when we come back this way again!!!
author: Sandy R.

description:
Best damn Fish and Chips ever. SAUCY!

To be honest, all of Fisherman's wharf is good. I just happened to walk into this one and liked it. but they're all good. this one is good too. enjoy everyone!
author: Mr. T.

description: There are many options for fried seafood stand... they offer delicious crab cakes here.  That was the difference for us compared to the 5 other stands just 20 feet away.  It was a good choice!... I'm talking about the outside stand here
author: Rachel S.

description:
Almost couldnt bear to walk in here.  Hate restaurants where the host tries to lure you in.  And it looked like the worst tourist trap in the minefield of tourist traps that is the Wharf.  And there were families with kids doing that thing where they scream for no reason and climb on the backs of booths.  (I heard its called being a kid.)  

But it was late.  And cold.

Clam chowder was killer.  Took me back to boston.  Get the bread bowl and add tabasco.  Fresh crab was awesome as well.  

I had my doubts, but now I see the light.  house.
author: Brad C.

description:
After perusing the multitude of fishy restaurants lining the pier we finally settled on Nicks. We chose it cause it was the most crowded, and figured this was a good sign. The first give away that it may be depressing was the sad little lobster eyes peering out of the stale water by the tank at the door. Sure, its the wharf (so what do you expect?) but I guess I am just not cut out for it. 

In some ways if you are going to brave the semi-awful camera flashing, cheesy smilin' and Hawaiian shirt wearing crowds of the wharf you better be able to get a damn great bowl of chowder, right? Well, I now know  that's not entirely true. 

The chowder was good, not great. The beer was cold, and  probably my favorite part of the meal (along with a chunk of fresh, yummy sourdough bread and the company I enjoyed it with).

I think next time I would spring for the more expensive crab, which the table next to me oohed and awed over, making me jealous and in the mood for more than just soup.
author: Natalie N.

description: I stopped by the outside crab bar, wanting some crab cocktail. There's a huge cluster of tourists wanting the same thing. Yes, I know it's not crab season here but the smell of cooking and boiling seafood got the better of me. For $5.95 I got a little cup of crab meat, cocktail sauce and those weird oyster crackers. I had a unsweetened iced ta for $1.25. I was still hungry but it did the trick for the time being. They are a harried bunch who work at Nick's..
author: michael s.

description: Conveniently on the wharf, they have fabulous food. I've never had anything there that wasn't delicious. Small and cramped to get in, out, and use the bathroom, but the tables are cozy and the service is good. Best lobster bisque I've ever had.
author: Katie M.

description:
When my mom gets a craving, she is one determined person to get it satisfied.

She called me early this morning and had a strong hankering for some good ol' dungeness crab, so she came with the family in tow and we headed to the Lighthouse.

Yes, we were at Fisherman's Wharf and Yes, after about 5 minutes I didn't care how many pictures I walked through. C'mon people, taking pictures of seagulls and deep fried shrimp is pushin' it.

Personally, I like to shovel food in and savor the feeling of being full, but when it comes to attacking the crab, it's a labor intensive process.

Don't get me wrong, the crab was great, but in general, I'd much rather have a mountain of crab meat in front of me to devour than chippin' away at an exo skeleton.

Overall, I really liked this place and I'm sure if I have a friend from out of town and they want to drown themselves in Tourist SF, I'll land them right here.
author: Mike K.

description:
A totally decent seafood place that is nestled between Crazytown and Tackyhairsville.  Fisherman's Wharf on the weekends makes me feel postal.  It didn't used to, but I'm grown now, and I have found that I just don't like people from Strip Mall, USA pushing and shoving me from every which way.  Lesson re-learned: stay away from tourist traps on the weekend, if you value your sanity.

I waffled between giving this place 3 stars and 3.5 stars, but seeing as how I was literally trapped in the corner booth by piles of strollers, I have to say that Nick's deserves its 3 stars.  Cause if a fire had broken out while I was there, I'd be one sad piece of burnt toast.  The chowders were good, though.  The lobster bisque in a bread bowl?  A solid 4 stars.  I'd pass on the crab cakes (blegh) and the fried zucchini (frozen stuff).  But I'd ordered the fried calamari again.  Delish.
author: Diana Y.

description: Not good. I got sucked into this tourist trap. Food was not great, service was slow, overall I will not be coming back.
author: Anne P.

description:
We needed to get a parking validation, and decided Nick's looked okay. The people weren't super nice, don't expect the best service as they seem to have helped too many tourist. Also, to get our parking ticket validated for an hour you need to have a minimum order of $10. 

We got the Lobster Bisque and the crab cakes. The lobster bisque is okay, more tomato-y and no lobster. The crab cakes weren't even made from real crabs, which they obviously serve. IF they did have real crab, it was mixed with A LOT of imitation crab. Ehh, it's okay.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Stopped by the pier to get a good ol clam chowder bowl but ended up choosing there crab cakes for myself and the wife picked the crab chowder. So we sit down to eat and after a few bites I realize that the crab cakes were made with IMITATION CRAB MEAT!!!!! VERY UPSET. For ten bucks so not worth it. The wife's crab chowder was so so. Few sad chunks of crab meat. Sadly I will not be returning to here or will strongly suggest others to try somewhere else besides there.
author: Patrick H.

description: Not an honest restaurant. Very unhappy experience. We got a crab which was not more than 2 pounds. But be charged 3.8 pounds price. Stay away from this place.
author: G G.

description:
I am usually too lazy to eat crustaceans.  I've never been a big fan of  laboriously cracking shells for a small piece of meat while getting my hands all smelly and sticky. But the day we visited Nick's Lighthouse I said the hell with it and decided to get my hands dirty.  

And boy oh boy was it worth it...  We ordered the lobster combination which came with half a dungeoness crab, half of a meaty lobster, bay shrimp, and large prawns.  I tore that tasty delight up.  I started slowly with the little cocktail shrimp with my fork, then rolled up my sleeves to peel a prawn, and then ended up ravenously taking apart and devouring the crab and lobster.

All I can say is thank goodness for wet naps... and thank goodness for Nick's Lighthouse seafood.  The fried calamari was good too.  They give you a generous amount of crispy tentacles.
author: Maria L.

description: Got suckered into eating in the sit-down restaurant in back when we wanted to eat at the crab stand.  Then we were told we couldn't order food from the crab stand to eat in the restaurant, so we got 1 dungeness crab for $30 and a bowl of clam chowder for $7 off their menu.  The chowder was just ok, but the crab was good - just not for $30, since I'm pretty sure it'd be cheaper at the crab stand.  The crab came with a side salad with small shrimp and chick peas, which was a pleasant surprise.
author: Nancy Y.

description: Below average clam chowder, but even worse were the fish and chips: be warned, these were pre-cooked and served cold. :-(
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I love Fisherman's Wharf.  Where else can you immerse into total tourism, kitschy stores, bright lights, all day long and long into the night and man, everyone is always so happy bc they are all on vacation!  

Monday night at 7:30 pm, super quiet all around the wharf, but as always at the heart of the wharf, the first few street stands and corresponding small-ish casual dining rooms are stil bustling.  We cruised the strip, and the touter at Nick's seemed nice enough.  Sure, the booth would have been cramped for more than 2, clear sound of lots of dishes banging around in the kitchen, very kitchsy grape-shaped lights, but our waitress was super friendly and I like the charm of all the random old SF photos and posters, new and old.  

Warm sourdough bread.  Ah, the taste of sourdough is a true reminder of where we are.  Despite (or esp?) with the fancy new Boudin bakery building in view just across the street.  Why does sourdough bread beg for slathering of butter?  

13.95 for Red Snapper special, allegedly sauteed in garlic, lemon, butter, and caper sauce, was *exactly* what I expected:  totally mediocre.  Not that flavorful, squeezed lots of lemon on, capers weren't that salty, sauce was bland.  I always do enjoy the super fluffy Uncle-Ben's type rice, soaked in more lemon.  Steamed veggies were pretty ok.  Bowl of clam chowder that came with my meal was thick, a little salty, but flavorful.  And the right oyster crackers!

11.95 for Fresh Fish and Chips special:  ok.  Breaded in cornmeal, the fries were OK, the fish was OK, the cole slaw was OK, the tartar sauce was pretty good.  Bowl of lobster bisque that came with this meal was again thick, a little salty, but still flavorful.  Again, those oyster crackers!

Ice cold water through a super skinny red mixer straw was fun.  

So, the food was probably more like 2 stars, but it's exactly what you get, and I add one star bc I love the wharf.  The place was packed the entire time we were there, the booth seats slide up when you slide forward a little bit, not to mention were a little saggy, but seriously, you don't go to these little strip restaurants for the food, do you?  (Nor do many locals go to the wharf and buy those fleece vests that have SF emblazoned on them....)
author: Isabel M.

description:
Visit: 9/21/09 - Lunch.  Carpaccio and half crab.

I came here before and I loved it.  It's not so good any more.

Carpaccio was not tasty.

Half crab was good but expensive.

Service was okay.

Price expensive.

I won't come back.
author: Christopher C.

description: Being a newbie to the fish market and due to laziness of not wanting to eat outside, I got hustled in to this restaurant.  Our waiter was super cool and very attentive.  He let us modify a couple items under their lunch special.  Their clam chowder was really good.  Also had their crab cocktail.  I guess Im not really used to eating dungeness.  It tasted a lil dry?! Too much snow crab at www.crabhutsd.com probably altered my crab taste buds. Their fish & chips was delicious.  Lightly battered and meaty pieces of cod.
author: J L.

description:
We took our parents (who are visiting us from India) to Nick's Lighthouse because we had been there once before and loved the fried fish and tiger prawns. Needless to say the space is always a concern,  the guy who took you order was in great hurry and acted as if we should not ask him any questions. The prices inside are much higher compared to the stalls outside which is understandable and that is not my concern at all. 

For me three big negatives were and explains the two star:
1) The food was very mediocre for the price.

2) Bad service and our server smiled only after making sure we ordered over the $10 per person benchmark for this restaurant. It is written in fine print on the menu card also and our server had this same condescending attitude the last we visited this place. 

3) The last and the biggest negavtive was that our server added the tip by himself on our check and made sure we paid him 20%. I am usually a big supporter of tipping the server/waiter but this act was plain annoying....I felt like telling him to f*&% off big time. What bullshit man, I really want to know if they did this only to us or are they this shameless all the time.
author: Jeev S.

description:
Don't fall for all the crowd outside! They're all probably waiting to eat at the market stand in front of it, which is where we should have eaten. Food was not impressive at all, and really overpriced. Service was ok, although our server was weird. 

Would most definitely not go back!
author: Melissa H.

description:
i think i can go 10 years until i have another clam chowder in a sour dough bread bowl on the pier.


i don't think i ever want to eat cesar salad or have a sprite from Nick's either. 

one star for good bread and fish. fish and chips portion size was lamentable.
author: Lily M.

description:
Poor quality of food. Poor service and never again, will we step into their restaurant again. 
It was NYE  when we were spending the last day of 2010 in the city, while walking around the wharf, my bf and I wanted some good seafood. 
So our theory is if the place is busy, the food must be good. But this theory sure did back fire on us this time. Sucks but true. 
Michael (bf) ordered his usual FISH & CHIPS, hoping that it'll be fresh fish and good fries. I ordered their, Calamari Stake and again hoping that their sea food would be fresh. We tried their clam chowder and it was full of potato and the flavor was different from others which was good but there were barely any clams in our soup. 

Our order came and the presentation it self wasn't appetizing at that point we were already disappointed and lost our appetite. 
We kept an open mind hope that it wasn't just the presentation but it only took one bite to know that we picked the wrong restaurant to have lunch at. 
At places like these, we'd expect to have their seafood fresh but instead we got frozen fish and calamari. 

I'd re-think about entering this restaurant twice, from our experience it was more than just a disappointment.
author: MC C.

description:
OK...so the ONLY reason I've even decided on giving this place 2 stars is because I had a great 1st experience...2nd, Not so peachy.  

1st experience: While walking the wharf, my family and I came across this neat little place where the seafood was prepared right along the side of the road...it was just everything San Francisco...fresh crab with a side of garlic butter and a beer right on the street...i loved every bit of it. Because of my first experience My BF and I (along with sister and brother in law) decided to make a stop here again since we had such a great first experience...boy were we SADLY DISAPPOINTED.

2nd experience: We decided since my sister is pregnant to sit inside and eat rather than enjoy the outdoor stand up informal curb side brown baggie beer that we did last time. It's way little inside. The waiter was HORRIBLE...we waited to even get our drink orders for a good while. refills of water let alone Sodas were impossible. This time around we ordered off the menu, fried calamari, sauteed shellfish platter, new york steak sandwich, fresh blue point oysters, and spinach linguine portifino. DISGUST! The calamari was mediocre..nothing spectacular despite how RIDICULOUSLY OVER PRICED IT WAS. Oysters were not shucked (you would think....a place that charged as much as they do would've shucked them) The sauteed shellfish platter (AGAIN RIDICULOUSLY PRICED) consisted of over cooked crab, TINY (AND I MEAN ITTY BITTY) little shrimp, squid, scallops, and some other stuff thrown together and sooo flavorless. This dish came with vegetables (that were the highlight of the meal for me) and rice..OMG HARD CRUSTY grains of rice. The new york steak was soo plain and sour dough was beyond the normal toughness I just about cut the roof of my mouth. And finally the poritfino was a tasteless disappointment...the linguine honestly had the texture of Chinese egg noodles. After this experience and our HORRIBLE waiter...this place would've EASILY gotten 2 thumbs DOWN if it wasn't for the first experience. NEVER AGAIN will we eat inside if we even eat here ever again. 

I'm gonna recommend just the front curb side area if you're interested. The Staff is friendly in the front and have a great sense of humor and the sea food is very fresh. DO NOT SIT INSIDE..you will be greatly disappointed. And ordering anything other than the fresh or deep fried stuff is a NO GO. So sad, I liked the first experience so much and the second one just completely ruined it for me.
author: Sai K.

description:
If you've never been to Fisherman's Wharf the most popular area there is Pier 39 which has a nice string of booths filled with crab, clam chowder, shrimp cocktails, and all kinds of wonderful fresh seafood. The problem that most people have with said booths are the price.. its really not that cheap. You're looking at a sourdough bread bowl of clam chowder for about $6, a steamed crab at $10 a pound, and a $7 shrimp cocktail. Of course, the attraction is that since the food is so close to the bay its going to be fresher. The crab is definitely going to be fresh before you eat it.. the crab is still very much moving before you heartless wenches snuff out its life in a giant vat of boiling water

How will Mr. Crab provide for his family if he's dead? *sigh* what a cruel world we live in. But since I am Chinese, I've helped with the genocide of the crab population. =P

If you've ever been to the strip of booths you would notice that every booth has a restaurant right next to it. Almost every booth (could be every) is actually just a small food outlet for quick eats that is owned by the enjoining restaurant.

So for our dining enjoyment we picked Nick's Lighthouse. What did we base our decision on?

    * Is there an amazing clam chowder?
    * Does their crab crack readily beneath your fingertips?
    * Do they validate 3 hours of parking so you don't have to pay any money for this tourist trap we call Fisherman's Wharf Pier 39 parking?

If you picked #3, then you know how cheap I am, and you'd be absolutely right. Luckily our choice wasn't a failure since the food actually turned out quite nice.

You walk past all the boiling vats of water, glasses of shrimp and into a bustling restaurant with tables/seats packed closely together. A table of four is expected to sit at a booth meant for 2 large sized people. With Ryan and I there we already met the requirement so it was a pretty tight squeeze. We quickly ordered because by this time, I haven't had a bite to eat for a good 7 hours (which is an atrocity that always should be immediately rectified).

Kathy's main goal in coming to Fisherman's Wharf was to eat clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl (speaking of which has anyone seen the new Bourdin Sourdough Bakery store? WOWSERS! that thing is gigantic!) so she ordered... clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. I asked her if it'd be enough and she nodded yes. (Later we would learn.. it was not enough due to the dent in my entree).

I'm not sure how much Kathy liked the clam chowder but I loved it from the spoonful I took. If you like Monterey Style thin soupy clam chowder this is the chowder for you. I've never been a fan of the thick ultra creamy clam chowder (which Kathy is, but she said she liked it). I like mine thin with a little bit of cream but just packed with clam and potatoes. Luckily this soup met all my expectations! Its the perfect type of clam chowder to put crackers in because the crackers just absorb right in. Usually when its nice and thick the crackers still have their crunch because it can't absorb all that heavy cream.

A+++++ clam chowder! Reminds me of when I was a little boy buying a quart of Monterey Clam Chowder on the Monterey Boardwalk warming up from the steaming goodness.

Next we have a seafood pasta with spinach linguine.

Tons and tons of seafood piled in here. Giant Tiger Shrimp, clams, mussels, and diced tomatoes. Just a really great crustacean mix in the pasta. I didn't have the opportunity to try any but it sure did look tasty!

Finally, my dish, something I affectionately call the Heart Attack. A giant heaping serving of cholesterol and death. AKA: Fried Crab Legs, Scallops, Prawns, Oysters, Calamari, and Fish.

This was heaven on a plate. The crab legs were so moist under the fried batter, when you bite into it and with a lil tug with your teeth, the crab parts like the Red Sea. Just giant chunks of crab legs fried. You don't have to deal with cracking the shell or anything!

Great pieces of Calamari, the perfect thickness where you can pop it in your mouth, chew a few times and swallow. The scallops were great, the fish was super moist like the crab, and the prawns were giant giant fried shrimp.

I mean .. you really can't go wrong with fried food. The only bad fried seafood is when the meat is just too stringy and disgusting. But its so incredibly hard to mess it up, you really have to go out of your way to buy 1 week old seafood to make it taste bad. The only odd thing was the fried oyster. Its kinda weird when its a little bit crunchy on the outside and then gooey on the inside. *shivers*. Decent quality oysters but the two and two just don't match for me.

The home made tartar sauce was also A+! Just the right amount of zing to it!

So if you're ever in the neighborhood and you need your parking validated, give Nick's a try!
author: Charlie F.

description:
We're visiting SF from LA and just love the seafood stands on Fisherman's Wharf. Since all the stands serve pretty much the same type of food for the same price, there was no particular reason why we happened to pick this stand. We didn't go into the restaurant; we just ordered crab from the stand. It cost $10.95 per lb, and they expertly chopped up, cleaned, and packed the crab to go. The crab was perfect, really delicious. They gave us some seafood sauce and wedges of lemon, but I didn't like the seafood sauce at all. It tasted a little funky. I know this might sound weird, but I like eating my steamed crab plain or with ketchup. I had saved some ketchup packets from McDonald's earlier in the day, so I was good to go.

My husband ordered a crab sandwich, which cost about $6.95. He liked it, but I didn't think it was that great. I suggest that you stick to the seafood in its natural form. Next time I might be tempted to try the raw oysters or the other seafood offerings.

I know a lot of the locals complain that Fisherman's Wharf is too touristy, but as a tourist, I think it's great! I love all the tacky souvenier shops, the busy atmosphere, and the seafood stands. I even bought myself a cheap but cute jacket from one of the stalls - I had forgotten how COLD San Francisco can be in the summers. If you're coming from LA and it's boiling hot there, it feels gross and wrong to pack a jacket, warm pants, and other winter clothes in August...but you really need this stuff in SF.
author: Shorty P.

description: Walking along Fisherman's Wharf and eating some fresh crab, shrimp, and calamari from an outdoor stand is a typical SF tourist experience, but once in a while its also just a nice break from your typical shi-shi eat-in restaurant.  Where else can you get a whole crab, clam chowder, and beer for $35?!  Get your hands dirty and enjoy the smells!
author: Annie C.

description: Worst experience ever!! Awful, awful service; they forgot half of our food. If you sit near the bathroom, it smells like urine.  I do NOT recommend  eating here, although the food wasn't that bad.
author: Karen S.

description: Stopped in Nick's for soup. The booths were very small and on a slant. When people sat in the booth behind me, I felt every move they made. This may be old school but it was unpleasant. My soup was luke warm while my mother's was nearly boiling! The soups were just ok. Honestly, I've had better lobster bisque from the grocery store! Though an employee constantly swept the floors, there was food and trash everywhere! I'm not sure what he was actually sweeping. Finally, the bathroom was less than desirable. Dirty bathroom=dirty kitchen...? I don't see myself eating here again.
author: Shavonne K.

description: At first glance, the prices seemed reasonable.. but then we tried their food, and left rather disappointed. They can get away with it though, because they're situated in tourist central. I'm not a big fan of clam, so when I saw crab chowder on their menu, I was pretty excited. There was no reason to be. Even the clam chowder my friend ordered was too salty, and the fettucine with shrimp and scallop tasted more like a microwave dinner. Bottom line, save your money and don't come here.
author: Sophia B.

description: I walked by and figured, here I am at Fisherman's wharf, I may as well try a cup of the $6 clam chowder. Bad move.
