First of all it is extremely goopy - clearly they add a lot of corn starch or flour. It has little flavor. I say, skip eating around here and go to a decent restaurant elsewhere.
author: Laurence S.

description: My boyfriend and I went here last month on New Year's Day and I didn't think it was anything special.  I had calamari and fries with the lobster bisque which was not too bad and he had some seafood pasta - which was ok.  The food wasn't the best and I thought it was over priced. I really didn't like the inside either since it's too cramped! I'm sure there are other restaurants that are better and I don't think I'd go back.
author: Kristine W.

description: We came here yesterday thinking we were going to Alioto's. We came in anyway because they were able to seat us right away. Their lunch specials came with your choice of soup or salad. My husband and I opted for their Lobster Bisque. OUr server came back with one clam chowder and one bisque. the good thing is she let me keep the chowder and brought me another cup of lobster bisque. I thought both the chowder and bisque needed some spicing up. THe chowder barely had anything in it and tasted bland (not creamy at all). The lobster bisque tasted more like tomato soup and had no meat whatsoever. On the good side, they brought us our seafood pasta alfredo, that was great. We also shared a whole dungenees crab and we basically devoured it. 3 stars for good and quick service though. This place is really small, creepy, tiny restrooms too. It was a good try but probably won't come back.
author: Diana B.

description: Ordered outside.  Fun experience! Watched the crab be prepared.  Lots of people hanging around and eating (standing).  Felt real, not like a restaurant.  The calamari was good. The clam chowder was ok.  Food 3, experience 5.  Staff was awesome!
author: Lorenzo R.

description: Food was very tasty. The clam chowder bread bowl very good and overall good experience the only downfall the bathrooms are horrible, very small and disgusting!!!
author: JoeNLauren P.

description:
the "best value restaurant" on Fisherman's Wharf.

My daughter always raves about the clam chowder.  Their bread is like the best SF sourdough:  thick crusted and very sour dough.  They keep bringing it to your table, w/o asking.  Great service! 

The booths are cramped and uncomfortable.  Nick's is noisy and boisterous.......not a place to dine romantically.

But if you want a good SF seafood dinner in a "touristy" area, then Nicks is just the ticket....yes, there are better seafood restaurants in SF, but none that are as reasonably priced AND give you THREE HOURS FREE VALIDATED PARKING ON FISHERMAN'S WHARF.

We recently went to SF on a post-Xmas shopping spree......because we thought the Wharf would be too crowded with Xmas vacation turistas, family voted to visit "Spenger's Fish Grotto" in Berkeley......BIG MISTAKE.....Spenger's is now a corporate-owned ripoff joint, while "Nick's" is still an independent family operated place.

Next time, we'll brave the Wharf traffic jams & go to Nicks.....LOL
author: Matt C.

description:
The crab we tried was not very sweet and was just okay.  We did get a fresh crab right out of the pot of water.  It was a lot more difficult to get to the meat, because they didn't do a very good job cracking it, and it was served in a tiny basket.  Ordering the crab was very confusing, because there was a separate line for ordering other food, but if you got crab, you ordered it first and had to go back to the other line to pay.

We did some crab chowder at booth #5 that was very tasty.  It had just the right combination of herbs and dairy.  You could actually taste the crab.

Make sure to ask for napkins, because they don't give them to you by default.
author: Angel S.

description:
Me and my friend were craving for seafood. The problem was we couldn't decide which stall/restaurant to go to. We walked by each restaurant and took a peek to see which one would get us seated faster. We were standing outside Nick's and suddenly this friendly guy greeted us with, "Table for two? Right this way!" We were hypnotized, we followed him. We were seated at the very end of the restaurant (by the kitchen and restroom) and thought, "Nice! We have a view!" 

A waiter came by to give the menus and to inform us that our waiter will tend to us shortly. Fifteen minutes went by and still no one came. Finally a bored looking waiter came to our table to ask what we want for drinks, which by then we already knew what to order without question. We ordered Sauté Shellfish Platter which came with soup or salad and we opted to try their Lobster Bisque. Then we added half a dozen of Oyster Blue Point. 

The Lobster Bisque came first which we both agreed it tasted somewhat meh. I've had better.
Then came the oysters which looked so succulent! Their cocktail sauce was horrible, so stick to Tabasco and lemon!
Finally came the platter and we were floored! It was just a sad looking dish! The rice was almost cold and the seafood was bland!
We're not impressed!

Anyway, we tried to redeem ourselves by trying out their Steamed Muscles. We were excited! I mean, you can't go wrong with that. Right? But the problem was... Our waiter decided to abandon us after he dropped off our food. I was trying to get his attention but he was too busy looking longingly out the door for his shift to end. I decided to call another waiter with the intention of asking him to call our waiter. But he looked at us annoyed and said, "I have two rows of table and I'm not your waiter." and then walked away. Seriously, buddy??? You're not like the President of the Universe. Get a grip!
At this point, my friend found it hilarious with the many ways that I tried to get our waiter's attention. All I can say is fail, fail, FAIL!

Low and behold, I think that's because he realized that we may need to pay, he appeared. Magically, mystically. I wasted no time to order my Steamed Muscles because hey, I've worked so hard for it! Muscles came and it was just alright. 

Overall, if you want mediocre food with bad service, this is the place to go. For me, I'm taking my wallet somewhere else!
author: C T.

description:
dear nephew gobo,

i was walking in the San Francisco quadrant of outer space amongst the silly creatures and i approached the fisherman's wharf.   finally i was to discover wharfing technology!  i happened on a curious stand with food for the creatures.  a creature known by "Nick" owned it, as well as a lighthouse.  i did not discover any lighthouses, but i did sample what they call a "shrimp sandwich".   
the sandwich was good, but i think the silly creature "Nick" may have used a shrinking ray on his shrimp... very curious...  
still my travels drive me on as i look to unlock the mysteries of outer space elsewhere.

your friend,

uncle traveling matt.
author: Robert F.

description: My wife and I went to the wharf for fleet week and wanted some crab. We walked around and ended up at Nick's. It was ok but way overpriced. I have to remember anytime you go to a tourist trap be prepared to be fleeced. I live in Napa and should have known better. It's the biggest rip off on the planet....................
author: Mark H.

description: Ate here about 10 years ago and it was great.  Brought my kids back 10 years later because I liked it so much and it was awful!  Food was plain and drab and very overpriced.  Way too may good places to eat at Fisherman's Wharf to waste your time or money at Nicks.
author: Bill D.

description: Can you make what I am assuming is fresh seafood taste mediocre?  Nick's found a way.  Their deep-fried cod fish and chips and calamari both were over-battered, so much so that you could hardly tell the difference between the them.  You come away thinking you ate too much fried batter rather than savoring a nice meal provided by nearby coastal waters.  The pluses?  If you just get the chowder, you're good to go.  Also, the prices of the lunch specials are pretty good; I just wish I could have said the same for the food.
author: Chad C.

description: This place really sucks! The crab isn't fresh and they lied about the price! When I went in, I asked if the price is the same dine in or take it to go, the man at the door told me it is. But when I got the check, per crab came out to be close to 35 and gratuity for the three of us was already added! I thought that only applies to large parties! Unheard of! When I asked our waiter he told us that when they said it's "the same" means it's the same crab but not the price because it also comes with salad! Wth! You should have told me that from the beginning! Don't go to this place! It's expensive and bad quality! There are so many better choices around the same area!
author: Serena A.

description: We went here only because it was getting late and didn't want to search anymore for a restaurant for dinner. Bad idea. The food was barely warm and wasn't good. I probably would have rather eaten at the stalls in front or spent my money at a better restaurant.
author: Suzan K.

description: Avoid! Just had crappy crab salad sandwich and bland chowder. A tuna fish sandwich from home would have impressed me more. The prices here are too high to mention.
author: Lauren D.

description: The food was decent, but the restaurant was dirty and cramped.  Skip this and go somewhere else (or eat on the street).
author: Rob N.

description: Horrible service and the seats are really small and snug. The waiters are really pushy and they speak really fast. They just write down whatever they hear or just write down whatever they suggest without even asking. The crabs over priced. Apparently one pound is about ten dollars and we got charged 30. I think a couple of flimsy legs aren't 3 pounds. The clam chowders alright. They accidentally charged an extra dollar, which isn't really a big deal but they refused to fix or apologize for their mistake. Never coming back again
author: Stella K.

description: Clam chowder was bland as heck and I was hoping that it'd be more hot. The mozzarella garlic bread was good but I'm sure it's not that hard to make. Also had fettuccine alfredo with bay shrimp and scallop which was mediocre. Their calamaris are really good though, that's about it!
author: Vicky N.

description:
I am writing a review on the seafood truck for nick's lighthouse, not the formal dining area. I was curious to try their whole boiled dungeness crab since I saw quite a few lying on the counter and according to the tourist guide, 'tis the season to eat dungeness crab. Their price is 13 bucks for a lb of dungeness crab which is just too cheap to pass up! Well, it turned out to be a pretty bad experience for me. The crab meat was overcooked. I didn't realize until later that these whole dungeness crabs were cooked in this giant pot forever before they were sold to the customers. By the time I took a bite, the meat was flaky, bland and flavorless. However, I only paid 25 bucks for a huge dungeness crab so I did get what I paid for. I also ordered 4 oysters on a half shell for 1.50 each. They weren't so great either but I can't complain much since they are only 1.50 each! 
PErsonally, I wouldn't want to come back here again but if you don't want to pay a lot of money for seafood, this is not a bad choice.
author: yinmeng y.

description: I was very disappointed at both the food and service here. The service was very indifferent. The waiter never came over to check on us, refill drinks, etc after we received our food. I ordered the fish & chips and I swear it was like Mrs. Paul's or Gorton's. It was not fresh and I would be stunned if it was actually prepared on premises. This place was not cheap and was definitely not worth the price. We had to wait a while for our table and the only thing I can attribute to the apparent popularity of this place is its location on Fisherman's Wharf. There are several other seafood restaurants in area and I guess I just picked the wrong one
author: Lisa B.

description:
I am giving it 2 stars because the bill comes (at least for those perceived as "foreigners") with a "15% gratuity" already added by the waitress. Our service was good and deserved a higher tip but this policy caused them to just get that 15%, as we explained her.
Lobster bisque and chowder were good, as the cannelloni with crab. The fettuccine with shrimp, Alfredo sauce and scallops were OK. We won't be back for that not very nice detail.
author: Emilio B.

description: Awful! Some friends and I were walking around and a guy pulled us in saying he had happy hour and put us at a table, we sat there for 10 minutes without anyone coming for our drinks... So we left and thank goodness! The place looked dirty and crawling with bugs... Never go here!
author: Lyndsay B.

description: Okay place for a touristy location. Nobody had food poisoning, but you'll find better food anywhere in SF. Their street stall that sells oysters and clams has better prices, but they now have a guy there who can't open shells. He breaks them into smallest pieces. (((
author: Maria M.

description:
My family and I came and combined we had the whole crab, cod and chips, a salad, and cups of lobster bisque and clam chowder.  The quality of each of these things ranged on a spectrum from slighty good to bad.  Nothing was anywhere near amazing.

There was nothing special about the crab.  You are better off buying one at the store and cooking it at home.  You'll probably do a better job cleaning it and it doesn't take a lot of skill to melt your own butter.

The cod and chips were good.  It was nice that they were not overly breaded.  The fries were crispy.

The salad seemed to have cocktail shrimp (not fresh), canned garbanzo beans, canned beets, iceberg lettuce, and tomatoes.  Why so much stuff that is not fresh?  This place gets mostly tourists and I'm sad to think they might associate this type of food with this city...sorry, San Francisco is not about canned anything!  It's almost June, can't our Nicky put together a fresher salad? 

The lobster bisque was entirely pureed.  Was there lobster in it?  We will never know. 

The clam chowder...also mediocre--too creamy, and not enough seafood in it. 

Service was poor.  Got one of the orders wrong after we asked for it twice.  Booths were pushed too close to the tables.  I'm pretty small, and was still uncomfortable sitting in such a small space.

I haven't eaten at any of the other establishments like this on the Wharf. It's probably better to go outside of this area to eat.  Such a tourist trap!
author: Megan S.

description:
Although I don't eat crab but I dearly witness people eating any interesting food. My wife's friends came from New York this weekend and we took them to Nick's Lighthouse in Fisherman's Wharf to taste the delicious crabs. 

Last time my wife Shusmita couldn't finish more than half of the giant crab that she ordered, so this time she ordered only half. I had to work a little to keep my 2 years' son away from biting on one of those crab legs.

And my guests were very happy as you can easily guess. I recommend you to eat it there if you are in San Francisco. Don't forget to take advantage of the free 3 hours parking there which will save you the price of an entire crab!
author: Ashik U.

description: The person at door lured us in saying he would give us all free clam chowder. Come to find out, they give free clam chowders to only entree orders.  In a party of 10, we ordered our food.  Everyone else's food came in about 10 minutes. Mine took an additional 40 minutes and I ordered Chicken Parmegian with spaghetti noodles and sauce. hmmm.  When we got the check,  they wrote in 15% tip, but calculated, it came out to about 25%.  Prior to getting our check, we heard another guest arguing with a waiter about the check, and called the manager over. Wanted to get the heck out, we just paid and left.  As we left, we asked if we could get our parking validated from Pier 39 parking, which they gladly did. Come to find out, the validation is not valid and they are not part of the dining deal at Pier 39 parking lot.  STAY FAR AWAY!!
author: Mitch T.

description:
Visiting Fisherman's Wharf (don't expect cheap eats!) with some friends from out of town. After walking around Pier 39 and seeing all of the empty restaurants(hint?), we decided to look for a restaurant that had some customers in it. 

We walked on Embarcadero until we saw some live crabs. As we stopped to look at the menu, we saw lots of customers seated inside(another hint). The man outside the door told us that there was a table by the window. We felt very comfortable going inside. 

This was not white tablecloth dining, but waiter was exceptional. While we were ordering, based on what we wanted, he even told us how to get the most for our money. (That's better than most!)

Yes, the clam chowder and the lobster bisque were not thick and creamy, but they were tasty. The fried calamari had bigger pieces of squid than some other places. The fish & chips had better fish than some others.
author: GARY C.

description: On vacation in San Francisco and stopped by Nicks. The waiter and help was outstanding. Ordered crab and was amazing. The steamers on the other hand had a rotten steamer black gunk inside. NASTY!!! The bartender was an idiot though. Ordered a Long Island and it was nothing but Crown and coke.
author: Adams L.

description:
The food isn't anything special, the manager is new, and the busser/server will argue with the customers. 

I went there with my girlfriend, finished two bread bowls of clam chowder for $15 (which isn't worth it due to taste), and was ready for the bill. I leave my credit card in the bill cover at the edge of the table ready for the incoming busser/server to take it. He moves it out of the table instead of taking it to the appropriate busser/server, and when I call for his attention. 

He came back barking at me about how he is not my server, he doesn't know who my server is, and the point of waitering is the customer has to wait. I asked him is it too much to find my waiter & deliver my bill to him, and he replied it's not his job. I proceed to ask if he understands what customer service is, and he continues to bark at me about how he doesn't know how to use the register.

We got fed up and asked for the manager, who returned and used the excuse on he was new, just been there for two weeks, and didn't know about the incompetent teamwork there. I originally didn't want to enter & just wanted to get clam chowder to go, and he was the one who was persuading my girlfriend to enter.

BOTTOMLINE, if you want clam chowder from them, just get it outside or find another restaurant. Unless you enjoy BAD customer service don't enter Nick's Lighthouse for seating.
author: Keoini H.

description: Don't waste ur time n money here...!!!!  Horrible Service, Food was disgusting n bland, way overpriced...!!!  Lobster bisque was salty n they take it upon themselves to add the tip fee to the bill n it was more  than what is suggested...  Will NEVER, EVER step foot there again...!!!!
author: Lovetoshop C.

description: Disappointing.  I don't think our waitress spoke English.  The food was OK.  Not stellar.  Not bad.  Just OK.  But the bill represented food that was much better than OK.  I won't be back and wouldn't recommend it to anyone I know.
author: David H.

description:
I'll have to agree with the people herding. They are good at herding people into their restaurant. Being a tourist, we fell for it. Who wouldn't? :P 

The lobster bisque was pretty good. The waiter was pleasant and suggested we share a Hot and spicy crab and promised it could easily feed two. Not too sure about that. I was still hungry after sharing a "big" crab. Again, I've never tasted anything quite like this at home so I thought it was yummy. 

Went back to this joint for lunch one day to get fried calamari. Not a good choice. The calamari was cold and quite dry. I ended up dumping half of it away. 1 extra star for the tasty crab.
author: Arlene K.

description: Went to SF to yet another rainy weekend!  Ugh...so disappointing for us.  Well at least we had one nice day during our weekend.  We wanted to end our day with a bang, so we decided on crab.  Yum yum!  My aunt took us to the wharf so we can just pick up some crab and go.  This was the first place we saw.  They were just pulling the crab out of their boiler on the outside of the restaurant.  We got two crabs for three adults.  It ended up costing us only $21.  So we decided hell we might as well get another one.  Three dungeneous crabs cost us $33.  And let me tell you they were good sized crabs.  We got home and crabbed out to some delicious fresh crab.  Oh we couldn't finish all the crab.  But we definitely got a deal here.  I was a happy camper.
author: Michelle V.

description: I went to a few other places for clam chowder at the wharf but this one has been my all time favorite! They also have lobster bisque as well. They aren't like the other places and they gut out their bread bowls really well so that it accommodates more soup!!
author: April T.

description:
Nick's Lighthouse may have been around for a long time, however it must not be due to repeat customers.
I know that sounds harsh, but from our experience yesterday, it's true.
Where do I start...
We went to Nick's for lunch.  The place was not full.
The service was almost nonexistent.
The wine mediocre.
The atmosphere dark on a sunny day.
The bathrooms and hall to the bathrooms dirty.
(Floors in both bathrooms sticky...YUCK.)
Now let's discuss the food.

We started with the deep fried calamari. It was $10.75, and it was OK.  Not good enough to come back for.
I ordered the fish (cod) and chips.  I had a cup of the clam chowder with my order and coleslaw.  The coleslaw was pitiful.  It tasted like shredded cabbage mixed with mayo.  What's that?!?!  The clam chowder was really very, very thick potato soup with a couple of clam pieces thrown in.  The fish wasn't half bad although it resembled batter dipped store bought fish sticks.
My husband had the crab Louie.  It did have a decent amount of crab meat on top of an OK salad.  As he said, at least the salad had leaves and not just the center portions of iceberg lettuce.
Our waitress never did check to see how our meal was until we were done.  I believe the bus person did as he cleared away a plate.
Nope, we would not return to this restaurant.

Total spent with tax and tip:  $74
author: Carol H.

description:
One word to describe this place: DISHONEST! 

I decided to get some food from the outside stand. While I was waiting for my order, I noticed the sign they had up that stated the order is free if there's no receipt. I paid with a credit card and the cashier hands me the credit card "receipt" that shows only the amount charged to my card and nothing else. I ask her if that's all I get. She said yes. Then I ask about my order being free because there's no receipt. Long story short, the manager said that the credit card slip was the receipt but the cashier said that the charge wouldn't go through. When I get my card statement, surprise surprise, the charge is there. I call their office and speak with the general manager. He said the no-receipt, free-food policy is there to protect them and not for the benefit of the customer and that they wouldn't reverse the charge. If they have a policy like that, it should be straight forward, and they shouldn't jip a person who calls them on their policy by coming up with a technical excuse. When people think receipt, they think of something that lists what they purchased (the itemized receipt), not the credit card receipt. Just think about it. No one can use a credit card receipt to return an item. Stores always ask for the receipt that lists the items purchased. Like I said ... dishonest. 

As for the food, I ordered the fried calamari and my friends ordered clam chowder. I didn't have the chowder, but the calamari was rubbery, so that wasn't even enjoyable. It's definitely over priced for the quality.
author: Shaun N.

description:
3.50 stars

They make my favorite SF Clam Chowder and I also usually order
a side of calamari as well. I usually order outside and just enjoy my food outside near the bay but I have eaten inside as well and I have always gotten good service.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Three women spending a week in San Francisco.  We tried as many restaurants as possible.  We stayed on the Warf and had food from a few establishments there.  Prior to going to Nicks, we found that good food and good service didn't always go hand-in-hand.  Our last seafood experience was at Nicks.  Our server was Billy Ray.  He was extremely friendly, polite and very efficient.  Not only did he tolerate our craziness but encouraged our enthusiasm.  The place was PACKED and he still maintained his great attitude and sense of humor.  He was the absolute BEST server we had all week!  In fact, I think he was the best one I've had in a very long time - in many different cities. 
Now the food.  We aren't chowder people so I cannot comment on that.  However, the garlic, spicy Dungeness crab was INCREDIBLE! We also sampled the fish and chips  which was very good.  
Thanks so much to Nick's and especially Billy Ray for providing a positive and very memorable experience!
author: Lisa G.

description:
Had a bad feeling about this place from the time the waiter placed 3 pieces of bread for our party of 4.

Clam chowder was 2/5. Campbell's does a better job.
Fish and chips 2/5.

The seats are too close to the table and as a result I had to sit at sharp angle. Too cramped, overpriced, nothing special about the food here.

Restroom is located right next to the slot in the wall where the chef hands dishes to waiters. 

Employee of Nick's Lighthouse cut in a line of 4 guys to use the restroom. 

Not returning.
author: Shiva S.

description:
The lunch menu was plain and had a few choices each displaying seafood cooked in different ways. Their lunch special included a choice between calm chowder or lobster bisque and a shrimp salad. Don't be mistaken by the waiter or waitress. He or she will elusively offer you a soup in a bread bowl without warning you that you have to pay extra for the bread bowl. We made that mistake, an extra 4$ mistake. Dont be fooled into thinking that you will be eating small portions when in fact you will be eating more than you can imagine. The meal included complimentary bread and butter before you can scarf down your bowl of soup and entree. The waitress arrived with our soup as promptly as we ordered. The Lobster Bisque was a delicious bowl of red creamy, hearty soup. However, the lobster seemed to the missing element in the soup, odd for a soup called Lobster Bisque right?

After downing a bowl of soup, eating bread from both the bowl and the appetizer, you can't even comprehend why you ordered an entree in the first place. We played it safe, ordering only the Cod and fish. The Cod and fish was coated in a thin, spiced batter and the fries were cooked in a special seasoning. Sadly to say, the fish and chips were not out of the ordinary. However, we give them credits toward their coleslaw. The coleslaw was both sweet, savory, with a tangy kick. The restaurant was a quaint little joint with chairs to small for comfort and a meal bigger than the table can hold. Now we present the verdict; the KB rating. We give Nick's Light House a rating of 2 stars because of its overall service and lack of lobster in a soup labeled lobster. We also rate them a 2 because they did deliver on the amount of food they serve. Our request from Nick's Light House is bigger chairs and lobster in our lobster soup.


For more reviews, tips, and tricks check out our website 

http:// ratedkb.blogspot.com

Follow us on twitter @ratedkb

Like our Facebook page too! https://www.facebook.com/pages/Rated-KB/315992435102223
author: KB n.

description:
I know, this place is tiny, it is cramped, it is a little odd, the staff can be harried... but this is classic San Francisco. This is old time Fisherman's Wharf.  My wife and I have been here at least 4 times in the past 4 years. The food is easily better than the more expensive place upstairs with a nice view and the staff has always tried to accommodate our needs. They even let us sit in a table by the window in the back to keep an eye on our dog.

Good for: fun, quick food on the wharf.
Not good for: Romantic quiet dinners.
author: Micah B.

description:
So I hadn't been to SF since I was a little girl, so when I went, I wanted to do all the touristy things -you know, the Golden Gate Bridge, the Cable cars, and especially eat at the Wharf.  I knew going in that the Wharf is a major tourist trap...and I could tell...the abundance of souvenir shops were insane!  and the vendors on the peirs trying to lure you in...but I was starving by the time we made it to the Wharf -oh and not to mention freezing cold!!

We walked up and down, trying to distinguish the "bad" places to eat from the "good." It was hard, everyone has the same menu, the same layout, but no one's place was as crowded as Nick's.  So we say, what the hell, and get ourselves seated in an awkwardly small squished up booth.  Well, I was just pleasantly suprised. I loved the clam chowder!! It did the trick and hit the spot just right for our first night in SF. The food wasn't bad...the seafood really tasted good. If you're looking for amazing, creative, presentable dishes, this isn't the place for you. This is a down and dirty, to the point establishment...they've got food, you eat, you pay, you leave. But hell, you'll leave full and satisfied, so I guess that ain't too bad :)
author: Nancy N.

description:
I think Err's got it pretty down. Maybe I should just follow her around when she reviews and just say "yeah, that's about it"! It'll save me a lot of typing time.

I think the only thing I'd note is that the Lobster bisque kind of missed the Lobster flavor.

Other than that, the service was great and the rest of the meal was pretty good! 

I don't know that I'd come back again since there are so many places to eat in the city, but it was a good experience and it's worth checking out if you happen to be in the area.
author: Cristian C.

description:
Love this place. Recommend it to friends and family and never disappoints. Total tourist trap and as much as I hate driving in Fisherman's Wharf, anytime I'm over there this is must-eat stop. Unpretentious and delicious.

The lobster bisque is what keeps me coming back. Absolutely amazing! The crab is yummy and affordable.
author: Kelly T.

description: The restaurant gets a 3...service was poor, and food was just all right. It's the outside cart that gets a 5...which avgs out to a 4 for this place. I pretty much tried all of the crab sandwiches from each cart and nick's was the best by far! Their crab mix was just amazing...and yes, it's boudin's bread, but the crab is what I came here for! They pack their sandwiches, and it's just a joy to eat crab and drop it all over the place on your way to the next cart. :)
author: Dee N.

description: Pretty legit clam chowder and sourdough, but definitely felt rushed from the time we stepped up to the restaurant til we paid our bill. All the orders were good, fun atmosphere, everyone else enjoyed the seafood (that I couldn't eat). I would give them 4 stars, but I felt too cramped and rushed to really enjoy my food.
author: Rachel A.

description: Whenever my family and I are in the city, we ALWAYS go to Nick's Lighthouse! I go there almost every year for my birthday. I only order one thing, and that's their Alfredo with Bay Shrimp and Bay Scallops. It's the most delicious and perfect alfredo I've had in a very long time. Their crab chowder came out green though, and my boyfriend sent it back. It did look pretty gross. So just don't order that and have a great time!
author: Sydnie M.

description:
CLAM CHOWDER TO DIE FOR!
The #5 at Fisherman's Wharf, Nick's Lighthouse, established in 1934 but a place I've been going to since 1988. When I was younger I would act in summer programs in the city and I would always get lunch in or around the Wharf. When I would go to Nick's, I'd stand next to a street side table and get some of the best buttery creamy clam chowder in the land and its always great in a bread bowl. I recently went with my Mom and instead of standing outside, I enjoy sitting inside the maritime flair of the restaurant. After over twenty years of going to this awesome place, the clam chowder hasn't changed and the food is fantastic. On this trip I ordered a bowl of clam chowder with the spicy garlic dungeness crab and it was incredible. It wasn't hot but full of great flavor that danced on my tongue. I always look forward to coming back for more and if you go, try the clam chowder, it's to die for!
author: Jay S.

description:
AWFUL ! I cannot believe this place gets an overall of a  3 1/2 stars. Seriously my little 7 years old sister can serve me with the dishes they served my boyfriend and I, WHICH may I add came straight out of a damn microwave. 

The food :
 1st - The shrimp that was on our salad came from a can.
 2nd- The lobster bisque was so-so , ehhh I can get it from my local deli store.
3rd- Halibut and snapper, ahh just horrendous. The snapper doesn't even look like a snapper. rather it looks like those fish from the freezer box you buy off key food or any other local supermarkets, and the halibut tasted like rubber with a littler bit of fishy salty water. EWW!!
4th- Crab cake was better than the rest. 

Reminder to all tourists, it is indeed in such ease for you to get lured into this crappy restaurant. Please... please save yourself and swiftly walk to the other side, or you can simply just yell at their faces and say " NO!!" .
author: tanty d.

description:
This restaurant is terrible.  Four of us went there yesterday and there was not a good dish among us.  The booths are incredibly small, even for the smallest among us.  The service was very bad.  I ordered a $28 soup which was supposed to have contained crab, prawns, clams, calmari, mussels, scallops and fish.  There was no crab, no clams, and the fish was grey.  The soup was filled with the spider-looking leg part of dozen of calarami.  It looked like I had been served spider soup!

My partner ordered the deep fried platter.  Another huge mistake.  It looked disgusting and tasted worse.  It tasted as if the oil used to make the food was old.  

To be fair, the ice tea was good.  But for the $122 bill we got for four of us, I'll get my ice tea elsewhere.
author: Ted G.

description: Really cool place. Very quaint. The prices are a litke high but everything around will be the same or more. Food is good but their shrimp cocktail has reallllllly small shrimp
author: Sasha O.

description: Amazing service, cozy atmosphere and delicious crab and clam chowder. Bloody Mary also very good!
author: Luna S.

description: Awful!! Some friends and I were walking around and a guy pulled us in saying he had a happy hour special for us. We sat at a table for 10 minutes without any server coming to get our drink order. So we left and thank goodness! The place looked dirty and crawling with bugs... Never go here! So many other better places on the pier!
author: Lyndsay B.

description: Our fault to go to a tourist trap anyway. We had the lobster bisque (salty and gross) steamed crap (cold and tough) and crab cake (ONE tiny crabcake for 8 bucks, NOT cooked in the middle and cold) We never say the waiter after he took the order until he brought the check. No refill on the $3 ice tea, oh well. Like I said, we deserved it by going against better judgement and eating at seafood disneyland.
author: Nicole F.

description:
After wandering around Alcatraz with family, we meandered up Embarcadero to Fisherman's Wharf and looked for a place with crab.  Since all of them did, we flipped the proverbial coin and went to Nick's Lighthouse.

I was a little unimpressed with the lunch menu, but there was plenty of stuff on the dinner menu that was also interesting.  The bread was tasty, but cold, the lobster bisque was yummeriffic, and the crab cakes and calamari were tasty too.  It's too bad they don't have crab cakes on the appetizer menu so that you can just get those instead of having it with a whole lot of sides.  But they're quite full of meat and flavour - almost no filler, if any!  We saw a crab salad walk by...and it had tons of meat on it.  Something to try next time??

I'd probably go back here, but just get the crab cakes (or other take out crab-related dishes) from the take-out counter outside.  Or go for dinner when the prices make more sense.
author: Adam G.

description: I dont know if its because I look young or because the staff is lazy but I went there for dinner on a friday with a group of 6. It was  about an hour til closing when we sat down. We ate our basket of complimentary bread and asked the waiter for more bread. He told us they had no more. A couple more parties sat down shortly after and guess what they recieved. Why lie to us when its something so petty. Its pathetic how people treat us because we look young but dont realize that we do see whats going on. The staff at Nicks are a bunch of racist bitches because they denied us bread but were so reluctant to supply non existant bread to their white customers
author: Ludwig M.

description:
Same here, My girlfriend and I just followed the crowd since it seemed good. The chowder was good, but not too great. I had the crab chowder while my girlfriend had the lobster bisque. I just though it was tasty, but not life-changing great. Had the crab cakes first, which was sort of disappointing, but it was good after the cocktail sauce.

3 out of 5.
author: Gordon F.

description:
Every time I'm in SF for business I make a trip down to the wharf and grab some crabs with me. (No pun intended)

I had the dungeoness and the crab chowder. the crustacean was fresh and the crab chowder was friggin delicious. I got the pint not the cup. Trust me its worth it. 

I also grab a crab sandwich for lunch the next day. However, that wasn't so polite to my stomach. The sourdough was hard as Mike Tyson's fist and I couldn't taste a single crab meat in the sandwich. I'll pass on this next time Im in town
author: Eric S.

description:
I went to Nick's Lighthouse last week with my wife. I ordered a  sourdough bread of chowder and my wife ordered a plate of fish pasta. When the bill came at last we found out there were three separate items on it, 1) the sourdough bread of chowder; 2) the seafood pasta and 3) the fish. I asked the lady server if she made a mistake on my bill by charging our meals, the extra fish that I had not ordered; she then explained to me the seafood pasta came only with plain pasta with sauce but she ordered for us a separate extra Halibut (only 8 small diced pieces) on top of the pasta but charged each item separately as follows: the creamy sauce pasta ($13.90), the extra Halibut on top ($25.00). It added up this plate total cost was $43.90. Isn't it fair to charge this plate with this scaring amount of money on such meal??? $43.90 for a plate of pasta with 8 small diced tip bit of Halibut on top; the lady server should have told us the additional charges on the fish before she placed the order to the kitchen. And to our last surprise, she even added the tipping of 15% on the bill without asking our permission to do so. I would say this lady server's doing was absolutely wrong and should be fired or be trained for her job again; her action is like highway robbery and this restaurant should know of this if all these are not the restaurant's policy. For sure, we will never go back into this restaurant again and will let our friends and relatives know about it. San Francisco Consumers Bureau/Tourism Bureau should blacklist this restaurant and send out warnings to this restaurant to protect Fishermen Wharf's reputation being further damaged!

We travelled down from Canada and would not have expected this thing would have happened to us right in such a famous spot in Fishermen Wharf in SF.
author: Brian L.

description: I walked by this stand and decided to order a cup of clam chowder.  I don't know if it's because I had really high expectations, but it wasn't that good.
author: Allie D.

description: First of all, what is the deal with adding celery to the crab?  How about everyone that serves crab sandwiches on the wharf take a field trip to Point Loma Seafood in San Diego and learn how to make a real crab sandwich.  Second, why is there no place to sit?  Why can't all the restaurants get together and fund a proper eating section?  I won't be going back, too expensive for mediocre food.
author: Chris D.

description: After a day of roaming around SF me & my girls ended up at Nick's Lighthouse near the Pier. They had fresh sourdough bread & good specials that came with clam chowder for $14.95. We got the fettucini w/ scallops & shrimp. We only had room to eat a couple bites of the pasta but it was overall an okay meal. Next time I would probably stick with just the bread & clam chowder. :)
author: Jessica G.

description: Unfortunately, I thought that the lobster bisque tasted very much like marinara sauce. I prefer Aliotos lobster bisque. On a better note, the clam chowder here was tasty and hearty with lots of clams in it. The bread they use is delicious is well. The sevice was wonderful despite a busy Sunday afternoon.
author: A. B.

description: I ate here twice on my trip - both times from the outside station.  I think the food's cheaper outside than going inside to sit down. The guys are pretty aggressive about trying to get you inside the restaurant - I think the same guy asked me four times to go inside because I kept circling all the stands deciding where to get my food from.  I got oysters on the half shell and a whole crab sauted in a spicy sauce for a few extra bucks.  It was SO GOOD!  The first time we did that, it was early evening so we went next door and bought a beer from the crab restaurant and sat outside under the heat lamps and ate with a nice view of the ocean.  It was pretty deserted so nobody bothered us, except for an older woman asking us for our empty beer can.  The next time we stopped by there we got the same thing plus the chowder in the bread bowl.  Then we stopped by a liquor store and got some champagne, then hightailed it back to the hotel a few blocks away and I had the best dinner.  It was DELISH and the oysters were rocking too!  Very fresh and sweet.  They will get you fresh horseradish from the restaurant if you ask.  The crab does get messy cuz it's finger food so have lots of napkins handy.  I just kept licking my fingers the whole time - it was that good!
author: Francesca K.

description: This place is good but I think it's a bit pricey.  If you eat outside it's probably cheaper since you can purchase everything seperately.  Steamed crab and clam chowder is a must!  I highly recommend eating outside if it's a nice sunny day.
author: Kim J.

description: The best service of my life! We loved the food and selection.
author: Chris P.

description: Bring on the fish and chips. The food here in fisherman's wharf is really fresh however this restaurant exceeded expectations. I really wanted to walk to the back and look for the guy sitting on the dock catching the fishes. I can't wait to go back.
author: Delroy H.

description: Whenever we are in town, we make sure we go to Nick's at least once. This is a great little, out-of-the-way restaurant. Small and intimate. Great food.
author: Beth M.

description: Pricey tourist area but can't resist the fresh crab. Headed here for lunch. Wife got the lunch shrimp skewers.  It was nothing to elaborate about. I got the half crab and bowl of  clam chowder.  Chowder was a let down.  I had better. Try the Crab Cooker in Newport beach. but anyway, the fresh half crab was the bomb.  It cost 14.95 market price. Wasn't enough for me but it satisfied my crab fix.
author: Eddie S.

description:
I had the spicy shrimp linguine... I regretted it.  Tried a piece of fish and chips... meh. Someone had the halibut (I think it was the halibut)... they didn't like it.  I tried a piece of the skewered shrimp... nothing to write home about.

Clam chowder, was just ok.

Boardwalk restaurant in a tourist trap, don't expect too much (not my choice to dine there).
author: Don S.

description: The location is great - right by the wharf.  The food is decent - not great though.  - My veggies were on the cold side.  The reason why I can only give 2 stars is because of the restaurant's insane seating arrangements.  The booths are unbelievably tight, and even as a fairly slender person you have to shoehorn yourself into the booth.  An overweight person has absolutely no chance getting in there.  This is the weirdest thing I have ever seen.  I felt claustrophobic throughout my meal.
author: Mike S.

description:
My Ratings:
Quality - 4 Stars
Quantity - 4 Stars
Price - 3 Stars 
Location - 4 Stars 
Service - 4 Stars 
Speed - 4 Stars 

My Opinion/Story:
Our new aunt just came from the Philippines and ofcourse the first place we'll take her is San Francisco.  After visiting the bridge and Ghirardelli, we got hungry and started walking our way towards the market area.  Joe's Crab Shack was so full we decided to go to another place.  We decided to wait inside Nick's.  The servers were pretty accommodating and tried their best to find a seat for 8 people in their tiny little cramped space.  After 15 mins, a family of 7 finally left and 4 servers immediately cleaned that table.  It was super fast that we were quite happy with it.  We ordered their specials since most of their dishes is over $15.  Their specials ran from $11-15.  Not too bad and it includes soup or salad.  I ordered their Fettucini with shrimp and scallops while the rest ordered the other items on their specials menu.  Quite satisfied with their dishes as they give plenty of it.  This was my second time at Nick's.  My first time was when I went to SF with my husband and treated him out for his birthday.  He got the crab and I had to fish out the meat for him.  That was the last time I did that for him because I firmly believe that people who doesn't know how to eat crab in it's shell shouldn't eat crab at all.
author: Cherryl D.

description:
We went for my mom's 64th birthday. She chose Nick's thinking it was a place she had been to a while ago, but was probably one of the other restaurants along this street. (let's face it - they all look the same from the outside)

I am not a seafood person, and my sister is a vegetarian, so we looked with dismay at the menu loaded with every type of seafood and very few choices for us. My 12 year old son loves clam chowder, but was thrown off by menu listing only Boston Clam Chowder, not New England. So he opted for the crab chowder instead. My mom ordered the salmon, which turned out to be the best item we got that night.

The crab chowder was surprisingly lacking in crab - more of a potato soup in a bread bowl. The Garlic bread, while not exactly burnt, was dried out and crumbly.

My steak sandwich was more fat than steak and served with nothing more than a limp piece of lettuce and a one tasteless slice of tomato on a bread roll (the bread was the best part of my meal). I had to ask for mustard, Catsup and Tabasco to make the steak palatable.

My sister took one bite of her linguine and said it tasted like it had been cooked in fish stock. She ended up eating the fries off my plate and nothing else.

Like everyone else on this site - we experienced the small seating arrangements, but we also got the joy of being moved to a different table after we had settled down and ordered. It was offered to us as "a table near a window with a view", but the view consisted of the trash cans on the back deck and a faint glimpse of the tops of some sailboats at the docks.

But my mom really enjoyed the Salmon so for that and the fact that the waiters were nice and understanding, I reluctantly give Nick's 2 stars.
author: Eric Z.

description: yeah this is good. that's all i can say. been there twice. had different meals each time. EXCELLENT. i mean, gee whiz. great seafood. the lobster bisque is the best i've ever had. the service is amazing. it's a great family spot, date spot, tourist spot, and local spot. i mean, gotta give them 5 stars.
author: Getti G.

description: My family and I have been going to Nicks Lighthouse for years.  Yes, there are tons of restaurants that serve clam chowder bowls, calamari, and popcorn shrimp but this has been by far the best.  We will continue to go there for years to come.
author: Jae's L.

description: It was Friday night, November 7, 2014. The manager who enticed us to come and savor their best chowder was really working the crowd and so we went in. My wife really love seafood and I wanted her to be happy because it's our first vacation in San Francisco. I was totally dismayed when we got the food; crab chowder with no taste of crab but mostly potatoes, and crab sandwich that tasted like tuna sandwich. My wife was totally put off. Then the flying gnats got in her sandwich and that did it for me. That's dinner with flying insects to add. I complained about the sandwich and the chowder to no avail. The manager even suggested we were trying to cheat our way for food. So I asked for the check and paid in cash (about $50) and did not bother to take my change and left. We are in our fifties and do not want to make a scene, we just want to enjoy the night but still, it could have been a better experience. To make a long story short, people DO NOT EAT AT NICK'S LIGHTHOUSE if you want real crab chowder and real crab sandwich.
author: Allen P.

description:
I stopped here the first night I got to SF. I was really looking forward experiencing the food down at Fisherman's Wharf and Nick's (the crab stand) really disappointed. I ordered prawns and chips and was greeted by rubbery shrimp and lukewarm fries. My guess is that the food had been sitting out for quite some time. 

My guess is that all the crab stands in the area are so-so. Can't be too good with smelly trash cans lining the stands. I would much rather have Calabash-style seafood back East. 

I can't comment on the sit-down food, but I wouldn't venture to try it after eating at the crab stand. If the food is the same I don't want anything to do with it. Curly fries weren't terrible.
author: Jeff W.

description:
The location of this place is very unexpected. I see these bunch of street cooking crab selling stands and behind that is this restaurant. I think it is sponsoring one of the street vendors in front. It gives a little crowded street vendor San Fransisco style to it, with the smell of crabs and clam chowder. I think this smell is a good SF touch to the restaurant. Not clean but that's fine for a crowded and compact SF Fisherman's Warf Location.
For food I got Cod Fish with Coleslaw and fries with clam chowder soup, this was a part of Nick's special. The Clam Chowder soup was good... hmmmm..  The complimentary bread they served was sour but I liked it. But other than that I was not so satisfied with Cod Fish because it was dipped in batter and fried, which I didn't expect. The fries was very oily and didn't seem like they were well cooked and some of them tasted chewy and weak. Coleslaw was okay, I always compare coleslaw to the once in KFC, which I think is the best. I am not very fond of the food in this place except maybe the clam chowder soup.
I had a taste of my friends Calamari steak, which I thought was very chewy, hence didn't feel like it tasted good..  
The one other good thing was it validated for the parking lot right in front of it, which gave me a free parking for an hour.
author: Leejo J.

description:
The price, service, location, Amazing!
The food and service was excellent. It was Sunday in the middle of August, so the place and San Francisco was so packed. We had choppino,  crab sandwich, clam chowder soup, and fish and chips, and they were all great. fries were crispy, chowder had big clams, choppino had great flavor. I want to mention 2 things. one is price and the other is about the portion. They had perfect portion. not too small or too big, and the price was unbelievable. my crab sandwich was about $15, choppino was $25, and the fish and chips was $12, and guess what!? I had a crab sandwich the other day from a food truck. Yes, it is called gourmet food truck but it was $18 with no seating. no service. you have to make a big line. my friend had a lobster from the same food truck and it was $20. In the middle of fishermans warf in famous san francisco, right next to pier 39, perfect location, and the service and price was just AMAZING!!!!
author: sierra a.

description: Food here is off-the-hook good! Some of the best seafood I've eaten anywhere ever! Prices are off-the-hook too for a cramped, crowded, noisy, hole in the wall. Campy atmosphere, waitstaff is organized chaos. Busy, but efficient. Pricey as well - about $100 (or more) for two. But you won't be sorry. Have some clams! Try the crab! Oooooooohhhhh this food is good!
author: Dave K.

description: The food is ok. I ordered the pasta with clam and shrimp. The seating arrangements are tight. My body touched the table when I sat down. The neighboring tables were closely sat next to us and I can hear their conversations.
author: Linh N.

description: Shimp sandwich, fresh crab, and fresh calamri.  All Brilliant!  Reasonably priced, and frienly serive.  I watched a lady walk back out onto the wharf and a bird literally swooped onto her food, grabbing a shrimp and knocking it out of her hand.  A flock of birds came out of nowhere and the shrimp was gone.  The staff was nice enough to replace the dish with advice on how to avoid the same thing in the future.  Even if they didn't, the experience would have been worth the $6 IMO.
author: Kevin V.

description: Most of the checkered-tableclothed tables overlook the wharf's fishing boats, and colored lights strung along the ceiling, art deco lamps, maritime maps, and old photos of the city add to the warm sea shanty atmosphere. If you're looking for more than a walkaway crab cocktail, this is the perfect place for lunch. You can order classics like oysters on the half shell or steamed clams, and the crab Louie salad is sensational, large enough for two to share as a starter. Cioppino, the specialty of the house (as it is in most of the area's restaurants), is generously loaded with fresh crab, prawns, clams, and scallops in a light, tomato-infused broth. They cater to families - there's a children's menu available - so you can expect the usual noise kids apparently are required by law to provide when eating out. The patient staff handles them well, and will serve you in a friendly, efficient manner, too.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Took the BART straight to downtown and then a cab to the wharf.  My other half had a business conference call, so although we went for the street food, we opted for a sit down place for lunch.  Packed and as we were being seated a line formed.  Fast service with a smile, I ordered the Linguini Marinara with shrimp (the shrimps were shrimps, I would've liked to see some bigger ones.), it was ok, tasted like jar sauce.  My companion ordered the Red Snapper Napolitan which he L-O-V-E-D, and it looked fantastic, except I don't eat fish.  OK portions pasta portions, salad was included, but all the sourdough bread we could eat was included in the price.  Overall not bad for the $43 tab (tip included).
author: Gianna A.

description: Even though this place is SUPER cramped, i still love it.  This is one of my "go to" places when we have visitors from out of town.  Their crab sandwiches are great, but the *STAR*is the whole crab!  It's so fresh and yummy and buttery, and cheap, too!  anyway, I love their clam chowder.  Pasta dishes are delicious, as well.  I swear there's like a whole crab's worth of crab meat in their crab alfredo.  Can't wait for crab season!
author: Eileen H.

description:
yes, i know, you know, we all know fisherman's wharf is a horrible tourist trap.

given that, nick's is awesome!  the hubby and i took a friend visiting from out of town here a couple weeks ago bc she wanted to go to the wharf at least once (we only allowed it once)... on a weeknight, the crowds seem to disappear.  we scanned every menu up and down that row of restaurants and decided on nick's bc they seemed friendly enough.  the booths are uncomfortable and tight, causing you to sit rather erect for the entire meal, unless you get that round half booth that faces the "view" of the boat parking lot.

clam chowder, lobster bisque & crusty sourdough... delish!  

fish & chips... fish was fresh but i still doesn't compare to my fave joint in san diego.

salad... comes w/ garbanzo beans and shrimp and is doused in a too tangy italian dressing.  skip it and get the chowder or bisque instead.

LAZY MAN'S CIOPPINO... so good, i think i saw the hubby get teary.  the sauce/stock was tasty and comforting and it came out chock full of seafood that he didn't have to peel or de-shell.  it was so good in fact that we ended up here again this past friday bc he was craving it and Moez (aka "awesomest waiter") totally remembered us and welcomed us back!

i had the canneloni w/ crab and shrimp and thought it was great... although, anything you stuff w/ crab and smother in cheese, cream sauce and garlic is ok by me :)

we'll be back... on a weeknight... preferably a cold and rainy one that scares off tourists from the wharf.
author: Carol O.

description: I frequent this place allot.  Clean and fast service with a smile.  Not sure what else to say but that i love this place I ate here twice just this holiday weekend. :)))
author: Roco j.

description: By far, one of my favorite places to eat on the Wharf and take tourists. It's bit touristy, but I LOVE MY SF, and I don't mind touristy, if the food it good. Probably, one of the better places to get crab, it's more reasonably priced considering the neighborhood and of course fresh marinaded calamari. It also, has a nice few of the dock and the sea lions.
author: Monica H.

description:
Today we walked around the wharf and saw this delicious looking seafood on the street.  We really wanted to sit down so we decided to go into the actual restaurant, instead of the outside part of the restaurant.

We were seated right away in a tiny booth where we barely had any room under the table.

Our server gave us some day old bread and took our order.  My boyfriend ordered some clam chowder in a bread bowl and a beer.  I ordered the fish n chips and a cup of chowder with a coke.  We both split the calamari appetizer.

We got our drinks and my coke was completely flat.  When I asked for a new coke our waitress asked if it was flat and said that the coke outside was better so she would get me a new glass.  Why would you serve me a a coke you knew was flat? I let that slide and we got our calamari and she brought us our chowder.  The calamari was ok and the chowder was not good at all.  There was not one clam in his chowder and I took one bite of mine and asked to change to a salad instead.

She took my chowder to the cooks and I could here her yell to them that I didnt like the soup so i wanted a salad instead. (2 other tables sent back their chowder as well to get a salad and she did the same thing) Then they started laughing and she finally brought me my salad which wasnt even fresh at all.

If that wasnt bad enough she brought me my fish n chips and I didnt even want to eat them from the look of the fish.  I took a couple bites of my undercooked fish and fries and after everything i couldnt  eat any more.  She brought us our check which was about $4o total for all the food we didnt eat.  She looked at my full plate of food and in a surprised voice asked if I was done, didnt ask if I didnt like the food she just took it away and brought us our check.

Also during our meal about 3 other tables got up even before they ordered, which we should have done in the first place!

Save your time and patience and skip out on this place.  There are so many other great restaurants with good service and delicious food to go to instead of this dissapointment!
author: Chelsey L.

description:
Had the most delicious crab chowder from the stand outside the first time I went. It was hot, creamy, very rich with excellent crab flavor, and several sizable crab pieces. The second time my friends wanted to sit inside the restaurant and I ordered the crab chowder again. Unfortunately it was only warm, not as creamy, and had fewer crab pieces. 

Recommend getting the cup of soup versus the soup bowl. You can save a dollar and not waste the bread. The soup is filling enough. 

You can get 3-hours free parking in the lot right next to these stands if you spend $10 at any one stand, which is easy to do.
author: Helen H.

description: This place is pretty good... this place is very cozy but inside is kinda cramped... the guy in back of me kept on moving and pushing me, so i was kinda uncomfortable... the food looked great and tasted great... the food is so fresh, that when you bite into it or even just by looking at it makes you drool... the guy from outside cooking the crab sometimes come inside and greet the customers, talk to them and even take down order... what costumer service... he's really nice... give four star is because the inside is too cramped...
author: Peter L.

description: Great time had by all! Huge steamer clams so good we had two orders. Wonderful cracked dungeness crab. Atmosphere busy, cramped and noisy like a fine italian family reunion! I'll be back if my travels bring me to the area.
author: Kathy K.

description: When I'm craving some clam chowder and feel lazy to stand outside and eat, I just come here. It does get really crowded with tourists on the weekends. The inside is alittle clustered..The last time I came the only highlight was that the server was cute.
author: Andy D.

description:
Very bad place to have seafood. 
We ordered the house special Cioppino which is very fishy smell, kind of stink. Seafood should not be cooked like that. 
The crabs we got was cold and must be recooked from those dead ones not fresh. Again, very bad taste. I ate seafood all the time, this is the wost place so far. 
All waiters do not smile, as if they have a death in the family. 
The place is packed that's why we went in but what a bad choice.
author: Lu C.

description: Hubby and I are regulars at fisherman's wharf, bringing new family and friends to visit every chance we get. We've grown to love the dungeness crabs, chowder stands and the "bush man" Today since it was a weekend and streets were crowded we decided to dine in at Nick's Lighthouse right behind their outdoor seafood stand. They were all eager to get us seated with space to park our stroller. But no sooner than we had walked in that we were utterly disappointed at the service and food. Our waiter named David was extremely rude. We hate being judged by service people because we look young and dress casually. When my hubby asked for more crackers for his salty chowder the waiter brought it over and literally tossed it on the table. The fish and chips were totally soggy and bland. Not to mention a TINY portion. Their oyster po boy would've been okay if the bread hadn't been grilled until burnt black inside..i can't believe they still served it! And their cole slaw...wet..overly sweet..that's all you taste is sweet. Their alfredo pasta with shrimp and scallop...no seasoning and very runny. The best thing about our meal? The two Stellas we ordered upon arrival. Of course it was good since the restaurant had nothing to do it with so they couldn't really mess it up. Will not be returning here. Please go somewhere else...try the asian seafood stand on the corner, they have much better selections and if you're looking for a restaurant in the area try the franciscan or even aliottos.
author: Francine N.

description: The wharf is full of crab joints, but Nick's is the best by far.  Most of the dishes (i.e. chowder, oysters, etc) are similar to the other places, but what makes it stand out is definitely the crab.  First off, unlike some of the surrounding restaurants, you get the whole crab.  Secondly, it isn't cooked until you order it.  I've been to some places on the wharf that brought me out a cold partial crab.  Unacceptable in my book.  Now whenever I'm in the city and want crab, Nick's is the only place I go to.  The restaurant is small, but so are all of the surrounding places.  I wouldn't recommend it for very large groups since the seating isn't really set up for that.
author: Noe G.

description:
seafood taste fresh.
serving portion average.
friendly service. 
a decent restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Truc N.

description: This is the place to try if you're in that whole Pier 39 tourist mood. I always like this place despite knowing better. The people are a little curt, or maybe they were too busy to be personable. The food was good, came out nice and warm, very comfortable SF type, its what you would expect. Give it a shot.
author: Gabriel B.

description: Yuck.  Crab Chowder was more like Soupy Potatoes and Corn Bits.
author: Rox D.

description: It was busy, we were hungry so we went. First off we felt rushed to order, also we felt like we were pushed into ordering soup. The bisque and chowder weren't good. Our crab came and it was alright but the fact that the service wasn't great and food was mediocre I could only give this place one star.
author: Jules T.

description:
This place is absolutely terrible, you're much better off eating at one of the stands outside. The portions you get are drastically reduced, not to mention the prices are far greater. We had lobster bisque, clam chowder, and one of their specials (some kind of fish and chips). The bread bowl was stale and cold, and the clam chowder was made cheap.. next to no clams. While having the lobster bisque, I had no idea what it was that I was drinking.. far too watery. Fish and chips were worse yet; I thought they would be ok since they were a seafood restaurant, but they looked and tasted like high school cafeteria food.

The place is really cramped; terrible atmosphere. Even though we were given booth, you could hear every conversation, and at the same time you couldn't move around without knocking over something.. like a table.

Service was terrible as well; after being seated, our waiter didn't come around for the longest time to take our order. After asking for utensils and napkins for the longest time, we just decided to use what we had, and leave ASAP. Once the check comes around, we find out that they charge a MANDATORY 15% TIP.. for a party of 2. Complete BS.

Never coming back, and strongly advising that you never come here either.
author: Vincent H.

description: of all places on the pier, it was the people outside who lured us in.  the man knew we were checking on yelp to see which restaurant had the best review.  he said here, have a sample of all our soups!  the lobster bisque and clam chowder are delicious.  don't have them together or you won't have anymore taste in the clam chowder.  the lobster bisque was full of flavor.
author: Andreal W.

description: Awesome clam chowder! Every time I'm near the wharf I have to stop by for a cup of chowder.  Nick's Lighthouse #5 does a fantastic job of balancing the potato to clam ratio. It's creamy, flavorful and you actually get clams! Yes! Plural form!  Kick it up a notch with a dash of Tabasco, I promise you'll love it.
author: Brian H.

description: I stopped in for lunch before heading back to the airport to fly home. A bowl of clam chowder, fettucini alfredo with shrimp and bay scallops and 2 pints of anchor steam for less then $25. You gotta love that. If I'm back in the area I will definitely stop in for a meal.
author: Steve M.

description: Restaurant has great food and service!! I take all of my out of city friends there... Delicious!
author: Tati C.

description: I had a combo of fried calamari and curly fries. And he had a combo of fried shrimp and curly fried. For beverage we had 2 fountain sodas. Grand total including tax $28.**. Unbelievable. The white guy who served us was more bitter than Chinese herb. The cashier was inexperience. Their line of work seem disorganized, too many bosses around but still not enough help. This store needs more training on the customer service, more speed on your service. This store sells hot chowders, fried seafood that NEED to be eaten immediately or otherwise get stale. The only problem really on the customer service. Anyways, save your TIPS jar'S' that are available in every corners. One is enough because it hardly fill.
author: tammy z.

description: We love to go to Nick's and have raw east coast clams on the half shell. Only place I have seen them in San Francisco. We also love the calamari steak. Great service. Our waitress remembers us and what we like to order.
author: Roger E.

description: This place had very good Lobster Bisque and Clam Chowder! I was pretty full.
author: Joseph C.

description: Really small place that rocks the seafood dishes.  I enjoyed my crab alfredo dish.
author: John M.

description: Each time I visit San Francisco's Fisherman Wharf, my first stop is always Nick's. They have the best clam chowder, hands down! Forget about eating inside, get a spot at the small counter, push somebody out if you have to, and order one chowder in a bread bowl. This is happiness in a bowl people. Put some oyster crackers in there, and a shot of Tabasco, and you are all set. Eat and enjoy, and don't forget to eat the bowl as well.....in all its soggy goodness.
author: Cecilia B.

description:
Had a tourist day with my friends, even though we're almost all locals.  We decided that if we were down at the Wharf, we'd definitely need to get some seafood.  This place sat us quickly, so we just went in.  The host was really nice  Between my boyfriend and me, we had the fried calamari, a crab cake, clam chowder, and the chilled seafood platter.  That is more than enough food, btw (spent about $50 with tax)
*Fried calamari - BF liked it, but I think it lacked a bit of salt. Fried perfectly, though - not rubbery, got the nice crunch going
*Crab cake - Had a good amount of crab in it, no big chunks
*Clam chowder - Not thick, more like a soup with a broth undertone. Not the place to go if you want something chunky
*Chilled seafood platter - The weirdest thing on here for me was the calamari vinaigrette. Not so much on that, but the crab, oysters, and tiger prawn (not deveined...hmm...still in shell kind) were all good.  Also didn't like the chilled clam on a half shell, but that's a personal thing - never had a clam raw before that.  
In general, this place has a cheesy tone overall but is a good place for families.   Everything seemed fresh enough...maybe next time I'll just get the food from the outside booths if it's not too cold.
author: Alice C.

description: Okay, so I'm rating Nick's Lighthouse pretty high, since my family and I think the food is pretty good.  Although we have a family friend who works here, so what we order is normally not on the menu.  Although the New York steak and prawns (cooked in Garlic Butter), which you gotta get it with fries.
author: Richard F.

description: Calamari from Nick's outside stand at Fisherman's Wharf is the BEST!!!!!! Forget about the fries.......get the all Calamari order. You will not be disappointed. Trust me.....I try to get my fixing at least once every two months. I love it when I have visitors from other countries --- I know for sure we are going to the Wharf. All the seafood is extremely fresh and scrumptious! I have yet to dine in their restuarant. Care to be a tourist one day and join me?!
author: La C.

description: Wouldn't go back if it were free. Wondering the Wharf... wondered into this restaurant. The crabcake appetizer, though SMALL, was tasty. As were the tiger prawns (but they were small too). My dinner, the steamed crab, was TINY for the price (hmmm, do I see a pattern here... everything was pricey and SMALL). Not 1 person in our group was really pleased. The fish and chips were... again a small order. The chips were the only thing tasty... the fish was bland and small. The lobster bisque tasted SO fishy it was just awful. The place was dirty, the bathrooms were tiny and nasty. A total disappointment. I go to san fran every year and avoid the wharf, but had relatives in town... wouldn't go back to the wharf again (too touristy) and if I 'had' to go back I would avoid this place completely.
author: Jennifer F.

description: A beautiful, sunny spring afternoon walking the wharf , serenaded by a gentle breeze off the bay and a tenor sax, remarkably on key.  Ah,  what could be better?  How about sopping up the left over sauce from the mussels over linguine, with a slice of sourdough bread, and a cold one at Nick's?  Work's for me!
author: Harry R.

description:
warning! the worst service I've ever experienced in the USA!
if you want to eat a sandwich o.e. maybe that will work. I myself had a 50USD lobster. it wasn't the money worth at all. my starter was forgotten, the starter of my wife came after the main dish...
author: stefan g.

description: visiting WF, thought to njoy nice crab, tried this place. Let me tell you, they treat you by the color of your skin, ordered crab cakes, and linguini with crab, what I got was a mix of crab meat with shredded potatoes, and spaghetti with marinara sauce, and 2 small pieces of crab don't know what. Thought they just ripped us of with absurd price, and cheating service
author: Trilok A.

description:
overpriced (typical for the wharf)

had lunch with my rents there, they enjoyed their split prawn & linguini entree

i suffered with my clam chowder breadbowl & caesar salad... really greasy & wierd texture for the chowder. salad was very typical & nothing special

2 stars for the free rosemary bread (fresh and yummy), and the cute waitress who was really friendly and warm
author: c e.

description:
yes... i chose this spot because of the name (nick)...

this is a sentimental spot for me... 
i know, the wait is long, its kinda expensive and the chairs are a bit uncomfortable... but their crab is good!!! i mean im sure anywhere on the grotto has great crab and chowder... but i have always had great, friendly service here... some employees are a bit moody but the ones who are friendly make up for it..besides..welcome to tourist spot #1 in SF... damn, its like walking down the night markets in hong kong!!!  
usually we will grab crab from a different spot then go to nicks for a tradition thingy!!!
author: Nic M.

description:
My bestfriend and I were at the Fisherman's Wharf area, determined to have some crabs for lunch. We walked up to the last restaurant and back down, and decided to stop inside Nick's for crabs. The greeter man outside the restaurant was friendly and we got coaxed in. 
We had the lobster bisque to start. Very flavorful, but it wasn't piping hot. Would have been much better if it was a little warmer. 
We ordered dungeness crabs. Yum! It came with some melted butter and lemon but I just ate them on its own. Delicious.
Overall, a decent experience.  Not ridiculously expensive. Waitress provided OK service. Be sure to park close by and check about the validation. That would save you parking money. Parking is expensive in SF. 
Good luck
author: Christina C.

description: It was raining, we were hungry, and this place was close. So we are standing outside and we are looking at the outside menu when this man comes over and tells us to sit inside and that the food is the same as what is outside. Alright, so we go in and they bring us our drinks and then give us a menu. Well, it IS the same food, but they charge MUCH more for it. So we ask them about this and they tell us it's true. So we payed for the drinks and went a few doors down to eat.. somewhere that doesn't try to trick you into paying more.
author: Krysta P.

description: you must order the crab chowder in a bread bowl- it's amazing. i was disappointed that there were no actual crab chunks in it- but the chowder was still so fresh and flavorful that it was easily forgiven. the clam chowder on the other hand was just okay, kinda bland...sorry to say i've had better in boston.
author: Sue K.

description:
This place is great. I've tried maybe 6 restaurants on the wharf, and this place always comes out on top. This is where I always bring my out of town guests too, and they absolutely love it. Why screw around with a good/sure thing. 

On top of that, how many of you know you save 10% here with your AAA card?!? I've been using my card here for the past 2 years, getting the 10% discount. That pays for an appetizer and drinks. So heck ya, I'll eat here.

Cheaper than any other place on the wharf with the discount...and consistently great cuisine.

Was only disappointed with the crab cake appetizer. Received 1 crab cake, thought we'd get 2-3. But maybe they shorted us since we were getting our discount.
author: S. S.

description: overpriced food,didn't taste too great. just fun to eat at the pier i guess.
author: a t.

description: Like other reviews thought the clam chowder was great...others with me had and enjoyed the lobster bisque although not as creamy as we like...steamed mussels bourdelaise(?sp) and steamed clams were also very good...Petrale sole or sauce was salty overwhelming the subtle fish...waiter, Chuck very friendly and attentive....overall a positive experience in the center of Fisherman's Wharf area
author: EDWARD C.

description: Really...GAG!  Three of us all had bad meals inside.  Trout...gag. Mahi Mahi...gag.  Sole...gag.  The rice was inedible.  I can only guess that the reviews are from the food outside because the inside food was old and tasted bad.  Just pass this one up!  Sorry.  The one star I gave this is only because I couldn't post it without rating it at least something.
author: a g.

description: We decided to eat here because they said "original recipe clam chowder" so I ordered clam chowder. However it was not my taste at all. It was like a caned clam chowder. I regreted to chose here.
author: Daiki M.

description:
If there was anything lower then 1 star, this place deserves it.

First we ordered the garlic fries, Clam Chowder and Crab Chowder.

The chowder was very thick and flavorless, as well as the Crab, didn't have any meat, we had to add pepper just to give some flavor to it. The garlic fries was a mess as well. They brought us fresh fries with garlic butter plopped on top. The garlic was so strong, you can smell it through your pores and was totally not edible. 

The server was ok... he brought the entrees out before the appetizers, messed up our drink orders and kinda argued with us what we ordered. We ordered a Coors Light, when he brought us a Bud Light. My boi doesn't drink bud, and we asked him "We ordered a Coors". He answered back "Ya, so you have your Bud Light"... Logic anyone?

It came out to 22$ for the two bread bowls and drinks. An okay price for what they served us, since the bread bowls were really small and just was a coffee cup serving.

Pretty disappointed with this restaurant in a famous land mark of California. You'd expect something with more quality, and maybe a bit more quantity.
